loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
In the picture appears Mrs. Leng L., who is 61 years of age and currently lives with other family members in a small home located in Siem Reap province. She is married with two children who are already married and have started new homes. Her husband is a car keeper for a small firm.

Leng L. currently earns a living selling a few groceries in a mobile business around the truck station. Recently she sold nearly all her inventory and she hopes to resupply her stock, so she is asking for a loan to accumulate an amount of inventory to continue selling.

loans.use: To accumulate inventory to continue selling

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Cette dame s’est spécialisée dans la vente des produits d’alimentation générale dans le quartier d’Ahligo à Lomé. Elle est mariée et est mère de 03 enfants. C’est pour aider son mari dans la gestion du foyer qu’elle s’est lancée l’année dernière dans ce commerce. Elle vend du riz en gros et en détail, de l’huile d’arachide, des tomates en boîte, des sardines et bien d’autres produits. C’est pour élargir son commerce qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter un nouveau congélateur pour se lancer dans la vente des produits frais comme la viande de poulet et de bœuf, 10 bidons d’huile, 05 sacs de riz et divers produits indispensables.
texts.en:
This is a lady who became specialized in selling grocery items in her district of Ahligo in Lomé. She is married and the mother of three children.  To help her husband with managing the home, she embarked on this business last year.  She sells rice wholesale and retail, peanut oil, canned tomatoes, sardines, and many other goods.  To expand her commerce, she's requesting  a loan from WAGES to buy a new freezer to get started selling fresh items, such as chicken and beef, plus ten containers of oil, five sacks of rice, and a variety of indispensable items.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: A freezer, sacks of rice, and drums of oil

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha N., 58, and her husband, Chhout Aum (pictured here together), live on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. They have been married for more than 30 years and have four daughters. Two of them are married; one sells silk goods in the village, and the other attends school and weaves silk at home when she is free.

Sokha is a silk weaver. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then resells them in the capital city of Phnom Penh. Her husband is a mason. Although the couple is elderly, they are still strong enough to work. 


Sokha has asked for a loan from Kiva one time already. She now is requesting her second loan of 500 USD to buy a motorcycle for her daughter to ride to school.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for her daughter to drive to school.

loans.name: Adya

texts.en: Adya N. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Bayanhongor Province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger." Her husband uses the family car to operate a taxi service, her oldest daughter is a university student, and her youngest child attends a local secondary school. Adya operates a small grocery shop near her home. She provides a variety of food products to the residents of her neighborhood. During the winter months, she sells firewood to boost her income. Adya started her business in 2008 and has made much progress in her first year of operation. Her earnings have enabled her to purchase a small truck that she uses to transport goods to her store. Adya is a very hardworking businesswoman and is focused on the future. She hopes to expand her shop next summer and says, "I am working hard to provide for my children's education." She is requesting an 800,000 tugrug (~ $560 USD) loan to purchase firewood to sell this winter. In the picture: Adya and her husband, Ganhuyag. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva's 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: Kiva Lending Team - XacBank-Mongolia. To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click: Mongolian Borrowers on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase firewood

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Plowing to expand her field and to buy farm supplies

loans.name: Mawuto Kayi

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente des produits d’alimentation générale dans sa boutique, dans le quartier d’Ahligo à Lomé. Sa boutique est très visitée par le voisinage qui trouve dans sa boutique tout ce dont ils ont besoin. Elle vend certaines liqueurs, du lait liquide, des pâtes alimentaires, de la mayonnaise, des savons de toilettes et bien d’autres produits. Pour disposer d’un nouveau stock, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter un nouveau réfrigérateur pour bien conserver ses produits frais ; le prêt servira également à acheter 10 bidons d’huiles d’arachide et divers autres produits nécessaires à sa clientèle.
texts.en:
This woman sells general foodstuffs in her store in the Ahligo neighborhood in Lome as an income generating-activity.Her store is much frequented by the neighbors who find all the items they need in her store. She sells some liquor, some fluid milk, pasta, mayonaise, bathroom soaps and other products. In order to have new stock, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy a new referigerator to conserve well her fresh products. The loan will also be used to buy 10 gallons of peanut oil and other basic miscelleneous products for her cleintele.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of general foodstuff.

loans.name: Nkiru

texts.en: Nkiru is 35 years old, married with 5 children. Her husband is a commercial motorcyclist and he also supports the household. She sells firewood at retail prices to her customers. Her greatest joy in her business is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She hopes for the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more firewood to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expanding her field and buying some manure

loans.name: Altin

texts.en: Altin D. is 55 years old and lives with her two children in Bayan-Ulgii Province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a "ger," which is a yurt, or traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her oldest daughter is 25 years old and helps with the family business, and her youngest, age 21, is a university student. Altin sells clothing business in her town. She started her business in 2001 after working as a salesperson for a private company. She has made progress with her business over the years and has found success ever since her oldest daughter started helping her after graduating high school. When Altin first started business, times were rough and she was unable to cover her daughter's school tuition fees. However, today, her earnings are stable and her daughter is able to continue her education. Altin is focused on the future and is working hard to keep up with her fast growing customer base. She is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~$2100 USD) loan to import clothes from China to sell in her business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: Kiva Lending Team - XacBank-Mongolia. To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click: Mongolian Borrowers on Kiva.

loans.use: To import clothes from Chine to resell

loans.name: Achayo

texts.en:
Achayo B. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase more brewing materials and make more alcohol to sell. Achayo is 22 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 2 children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar and restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more brewing materials and make more alcohol to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Having plowing done

loans.name: Bulgan

texts.en: D. Bulgan is 34 years old and lives with her son, mother, and younger sister in Bayanhongor Province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger." Her son is nine years old and attends a local secondary school. With the help of her sister, Bulgan operates a clothing business from a rented stall at a local market in her town. Bulgan spends most of her time importing her clothing products from China. Her sister run the market stall. Bulgan started her business in 2008 after having operating a small cafe with her friends. She is very focused on building a successful business and is currently taking courses at the Mongolian Trading and Manufacturing College to increase her business knowledge. She has used this knowledge and her past experience to expand her business over the last year. Bulgan has many plans for the future and hopes to rent a second stall soon where she will sell shoes. She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~ $1375 USD) loan to purchase clothing for her business and pay her school fees. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: Kiva Lending Team - XacBank-Mongolia. To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click: Mongolian Borrowers on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: A small wooden house located along the river belongs to Mrs. Sim S., age 36, who earns a living as a fish catcher. Sim S. and her husband have been taking time to fish in and around Tunle Sap River for nine years. The family has five school-aged children. Recently, this couple hasn't caught as many fish as before because a part of their fishing implements are in bad condition. Sim S. requests a loan to repair the broken implements and to buy more implements for fishing activities.

loans.use: To repair the broken implements and to buy more tools for fishing activities

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying manure and expanding his arable land

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 45 years old, married with 6 children. Her husband is a policeman. She sells local gin at retail prices to her customers. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.  Her greatest joy in her business is when her customers come to purchase her local gin. She hopes for the loan amount of 40,000 NGN to purchase more local gin to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more local gin to sell

loans.name: Gantulga

texts.en:
Jamgan Gantulga is 21 years old and lives with his wife and infant daughter in Bayanhongor Province in Central Mongolia. He and his family live in a "ger," which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Gantulga operates a computer repair business out of a rented stall at a local trading center in his town.

He started his business in 2007 in a room that he shared with his mother's hair salon. After succeeding in his first year of operation, he used his savings to rent a stall at the market. Moving to the market has proven to have been a good decision, and has provided his business with many new opportunities.

Gantulga is focused on continuing his success at the market and is already planning to expand his work area to include a small PC gaming center. He says, "I hope to have a more spacious and comfortable workspace in the future." Gantulga is requesting an 800,000 tugrug ($550 USD) loan to purchase computer parts for his business.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: Kiva Lending Team - XacBank-Mongolia.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click: Mongolian Borrowers on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase computer parts

loans.use: Stocking Merchandise in a Shop

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Mr. Meas N. is 36 years of age and resides in a small home located along the river. Here, he and his wife earn their daily income by fishing around Tunle Sap Lake. This couple is married and blessed with three children who are going to school. Meas N. needs a loan to buy more fishing implements which will allow him use to catch a larger amount of fish.

loans.use: To buy more fishing implements

loans.name: Horolmaa

texts.en:
D. Horolmaa is 51 years old and lives with her 20-year-old son in Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. They live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a ger. Horolmaa operates a clothing business out of a rented stall at the market in her town. She imports a variety of clothes from China and transports them back to her province to sell. Horolmaa started her clothing business in 2006 after previously managing a vegetable trading business for four years. She has found success over the last three years and hopes to expand her stall in the near future to sell more products. Horolmaa is very hardworking and uses her business to provide for her family. She says, "All I want is to support my son and help him find a good job so he will have a happy life." Horolmaa is requesting a 400,000 tugrug loan to purchase children's clothing and stationary items to sell.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Mrs. Pech P., 51, and her husband, Mr. Heng Lach, 50, are farmers. They grow many kinds of vegetables such as cauliflowers, bitter gourd and eggplant on their farmland in the village. This couple hopes to increase the volume of their products, so Pech is asking for her first loan of $700 to pay for plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide to use on her farm.

Pech and her husband (both are in the photo), live along National Road No. 1, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have eight children: four sons and four daughters. Unfortunately, one of their sons has died. Four children are married and live outside the family home and one son assists his parents with their farming business.

loans.use: To pay for plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expansion of Farm Land and Purchase of Fertilizer

loans.name: Lhagvadorj

texts.en:
B. Lhagvadorj is 39 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His wife currently manages a meat trading business. His oldest three children all attend the local secondary school and his youngest will soon start kindergarten.

Lhagvadorj operates a taxi service in his town using his car. He transports local residents to and from various points in the province. He started his business in 2007 and has had success as a driver over the last two years. Lhagvadorj is a very hardworking person and is known by his customers for his good character. For the future, he hopes to continue his success as a driver and use his earnings to help his wife grow her meat trading business. He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase machinery parts for his car and meat for his wife's business.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Savoeun S., 46, and his wife Mrs. Nary Phum, 45, (pictured here together) live along National Road No. 1 about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1990 and have two children: one daughter is a garment factory worker and one son attends a local school.

Savoeun has been driving a motor taxi for 22 years. His wife stays at home and does housework. She hopes to launch a business selling mangoes, so Savoeun is asking for his first loan of $500 to help his wife buy mangoes to sell and to repair his motorbike.

loans.use: To help his wife buy mangoes to sell and to repair his motor taxi

loans.name: Munkhbat

texts.en:
M. Munkhbat is 29 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". He currently operates a shoe making business in his town with the help of his wife. They produce a variety of traditional Mongolian shoes. Their products are very popular among their many customers due to their good quality and unique style. Munkhbat also owns livestock and sells their meat each spring to supplement his income.

Munkhbat started his business in 2005 and has built a successful operation over the years. His products display traditional Mongolian customs which are popular with the people of his province. His earnings have enabled him to make improvements to his home, providing a more comfortable life for his family. Munkhbat is focused on the future and has many new ideas for his business. He hopes to expand his product line in the near future and begin making handbags and souvenirs. He says, "All I want is to save enough money for my children's education." Munkhbat is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (approximately 425 USD) loan to purchase fabrics and materials for his shoe making business.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. loans.name: Narantsatsralt

texts.en: U. Narantsatsralt is 31 years old and lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Narantsatsralt graduated in 2001 from a cooking course and now operates a small cafe in her town. She opened for business in 2008 and has used her knowledge and experience to quickly grow her business. She attributes her quick success to her cafe's good location. Her cafe is located near a school and the many students provide her with constant business. Narantsatsralt is working hard to improve her cafe and already has plans to expand in the near future. She says, "I hope to grow my cafe into a nice, full-service restaurant." She is requesting a 1,000,000-tugrug loan to purchase a new refrigerator for her cafe. His oldest son and daughter attend a local secondary school and his youngest son is in kindergarten. Nergui manages a small grocery trading shop in his town. He provides a wide variety of food products to his many customers. Nergui started his business in 2006 and has since gained much experience as a businessman. He has used this experience to grow his business and earnings to a consistent level. Nergui is a very hardworking businessman and is known for his kind personality. He works diligently to continue his success in the future. He requests a 2,000,000-tugrug loan to purchase grocery products for his shop. loans.name: Reida

texts.en:
Reida S. is currently in the business of selling beer and charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Reida is 37 years old and is married to a businessman. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en:
Chhuon C. is a 54 year old woman and she earns a living as a fish seller. She sells fish that she buys in bulk on credit from a wholesale supplier and fishermen. She is married with three children and her husband works in construction.

Chhuon C. needs a loan to enlarge and improve her fish selling business to be efficient.

loans.use: To enlarge and improve her fish selling business to be efficient

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
S. Riza is 46 years old and lives with her husband and son in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her son is 15 years old and attends a local secondary school. Riza operates a clothing trading business at the local market in her town with the help of her husband. She imports a variety of clothing from China and transports them to her province to sell. Riza started her business in 2002 and has gained much experience in her trade over the years. Today, her business is growing faster than ever and is enabling her to improve her quality of life. She hopes to take advantage of this success and expand her business in the near future. She says, "All I want is to be able to save enough money to support my son." Riza is requesting a 3,400,000 tugrug (~2400 USD) loan to purchase clothing from China. loans.name: Sarantuya

texts.en:
S. Sarantuya is 53 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". Her youngest son is a university student and her oldest helps out with the family business. Sarantuya operates a meat trading business in her town. She provides a variety of locally raised meats to her many customers. She started her business in 1998 and has grown a stable and successful business over the years. Her earnings have enabled her to purchase a car for her husband so he can operate a taxi service as well as pay her son's tuition fees. Today, her business continues to grow quickly and she hopes to expand in the near future. She is working hard to continue her success in the future and says, "My dream is to provide my children with a happy life so that they will become good and decent people" She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~350 USD) loan to purchase meat to sell for her business. loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen has a stall where she sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She is 56 years old and is married with five children.

Helen is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Helen hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Helen hopes to own a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 20-year-old single man who lives with his parents. He makes a living selling computer accessories and is the source of economic support of his family.

When Ahmad first started his business, he faced a lot of competition. Many other shops offered similar services, but he distinguished himself by his determination and good service. He also owes his success to the support of his family.

With this loan of $2000, Ahmad will buy more accessories to sell such as cables, USB cords and printers. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more computers accessories to sell

loans.name: Anyeri

texts.en: Anyeri J. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and sodas to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar. Anyeri is 22 years old and is married to a grinding-mill operator. She has two children who do not yet go to school. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. loans.name: Sodnomtseren

texts.en:
Sodnomtseren C. is 48 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Zavkhan Province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her husband currently works as a loader at a local meat factory. With the help of her children, Sodnomtseren operates a small bakery in her town, making a variety of breads and buns that are very popular among her many customers. She produces on average up to 20-25 loaves of bread and 8-10 kg of buns per day.

Sodnomtseren started her bakery business in 2004. At first she had only a manual oven to make her products, but after several years of steady earnings she was able to purchase a more efficient modern oven last year. Her success has also enabled her to buy new furniture for her home and pay her children's tuition fees. Sodnomtseren is working hard to continue her success in the future. She hopes to soon purchase more tools and supplies to help her business and says, "My goal is to one day own my own workplace." She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~350 USD) loan to purchase flour for her bakery. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase flour

loans.name: Unurjargal

texts.en:
B. Unurjargal is 30 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". Both his young son and daughter attend kindergarten. Unurjargal has operated a taxi service in his town since 2004. He transports people around his town as well as to different areas throughout Hovd province. He has gained much experience over the years and is a trusted driver for his many customers. Unurjargal is a very hardworking person and is known for his good character. He is working hard to maintain his success and has much hope for the future. He is requesting a 700,000 tugrug loan to purchase parts for his taxi. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

Iggo, 38 years old and widowed, has four children, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a book shop.

loans.name: Bomkapre

texts.en:
This is Bomkapre K.. She is a 40-year-old married from So-so Town Lane in Waterloo. She has four children: two boys and two girls; two are in secondary school, and the rest two are in primary school.

Bomkapre has been a LAPO client for some time now and has taken two previous loans. She is a member of a LAPO union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Bopmkapre sells her fish in the village market. With her previous loans she expanded her business by purchasing additional stocks of fish. With her new loan, she hopes to add more fish to her business and expand even more.

loans.name: Urtnasan

texts.en:
H. Urtnasan lives with his wife and three children in a house in the Bayanzurkh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His youngest son and daughter attend secondary school and his oldest daughter is 19 years old. Urtnasan operates a transportation service as well as a business in the city making wood products. He transports goods and supplies for people throughout the city and in his free time makes a variety of wooden furniture which he sells. Urtnasan is a very hardworking person and is known for his good personality. He has worked hard over the years to grow his businesses and stabilize his income. He has used his earnings to support his family and improve their quality of life. He says, "I want my children to be educated so they will become good and happy people." Urtnasan is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan to finish the workshop he has been building for his wood-products business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

This is Zainab K.. She is a 30-year-old married woman from Tombo town in Waterloo. She has one child, a girl.

Zainab has been a LAPOSL client for some time now, and has taken two previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Zainab sells clothing in Tombo park including baby wear and undergarments as well as cloth goods such as handkerchiefs and wraps. With her previous loans she expanded her business by purchasing extra inventory. With her new loan she hopes to add more goods to her business.

Zainab would like to take the additional profit from her increased business and open a savings account at the bank.

loans.name: Magdi

texts.en:
Magdi is 26 years old and single and lives with his parents in Ramallah, Palestine. He is working hard because he is the only breadwinner in the family.

Magdi sells men's clothing. He tries to choose various goods of fine quality and attractive prices which allows him to keep his clientele. The business provides a stable income and allows Magdi to improve his family's living conditions.

The loan amount requested is 3,000 USD. With the loan, Magdi intends to expand his business and reinvest the increased profit in the business.

She is requesting a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Agnes is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa.

loans.name: Isatu

Isatu has been a LAPOSL client for some time now and has taken three previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Isatu sells palm oil at home. With her previous loans she expanded her business by purchasing more palm oil for sale. She hopes to use the current loan for the same purpose and increase her profit even more.

loans.name: Zainab

Zainab has been a LAPOSL client for some time now and has taken three previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Zainab has a shop where she sells alcohol, cigarette, drinks, sugar and other basic goods. With her previous loans she expanded the inventory of her shop and with her new loan she hopes to expand her business once again.

Zainab plans to use the increased profit from her business expansion to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Titty

texts.en:

Titty has been a LAPOSL client for some time now and has taken three previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Titty sells her cucumbers and leafy greens (such as cassava leaf and potato leaf – common staple foods in Sierra Leone) from her house. With her previous loans she expanded her business by purchasing extra inventory. With this new loan, she hopes to add more cucumbers and leafy greens to her garden plots, allowing an increase in her harvest and her selling inventory.

texts.en: Alice Moraa A., 19 years old, is married and has a two-year-old child.  She sells sodas and snacks to walk-ins and repeat customers  by the roadside near vehicle terminals in Kisii town.  Her business challenges are strong competition and up and down demand from customers.  In addition, she also sells cereals including maize, beans, and finger millet.  She is using the proceeds of KES20,000 to buy more soft drinks and snacks.  Alice describes herself as hard-working and ambitious and her dream is to own her own soda depot.

texts.en: Theresa is 30 years old, married with 2 children. She is a focused, hard worker. She is determined to lift her business above poverty. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She loves cooking and so she commercialized her skills by having a restaurant. She sells Nigerian cooked foods like 'eba', 'fufu', 'dodo', yams and drinks. She hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Kyaterekera Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Jesca is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a 35 years old, hardworking and determined. She is a married lady with five children aged from 18 years to 4 months. She hopes to build a decent house for them.

Jesca has operated a business selling secondhand clothes from Jinja for four years. Although she is able to make 50,000/= as profits a week, she is faced with a scarcity of good products for sale. She needs a loan to help buy more clothes for a steady supply.

Jesca is grateful for her loans because they help her have enough stock yet of good quality. She hopes to become a wholesale supplier of bales of clothes so that she could earn more from increased sales.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell

Fatmata has been a LAPOSL client for some time now and has taken two previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Fatmata has a shop in Tombo town where she sells building materials. With her previous loans she expanded her business by purchasing additional inventory for sale. With her new loan, she hopes to add more of the same building goods to her business.

If she is able to make an increased profit with the help of her latest loan, Fatmata plans to use materials from her store to build a house of her own.

Her business challenge is reduced demand from customers when there is drought or floods. Joyce will be using the loan of KES 20,000 to buy more cereals.

Joyce is married to a mechanic and they have four sons ranging from six to twenty years. Her goal in life is to have a big store and be a cereal dealer. She describes herself as social and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy five bags of maize and five bags of beans

He is using his loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more plastics, combs, wallets, nail cutters and plates. His goal for the future is to sell household items wholesale. Evans has a self-employed wife and three children between the ages of 3 and 7 years old. In addition to their businesses, this couple does small-scale farming. Evans describes himself as aggressive, motivated and development-oriented.

Kadiatu has been a LAPOSL client for some time now and has taken two previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Kadiatu sells goods such as cooking oils and fruit in the market in Tombo town. With her previous loans she expanded her business by purchasing additional goods she was already selling. With her new loan, she hopes to add more of the same goods to her business and make an increased profit.

With her extra revenue, Kadiatu would like to open a savings account at the bank.

loans.name: Bukari

texts.en:
Bukari Y. is married and has five dependents. He has been through senior high school. Bukari sells car batteries, fans, and starters at Abura near Cape Coast, which he has been doing since 1999. His wife is a petty trader.

Bukari uses his income in feeding the family, paying school fees, and utility bills. Bukari will use the loan to purchase car batteries, car fans and car starters to sell. With the new profits from his expanded business, Bukari plans to save part for school fees and also expand the business.

loans.name: Clementina

texts.en:
Clementina is 43 years old, married with 6 children. Her husband is a fashion designer. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

Clementina sells soup ingredients at retail prices to her customers. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of the family. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more soup ingredients to sell. She says thank you for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more soup ingredients to sell

loans.name: Kaleb Anekaya

texts.en:
Kaleb Anekaya N. has had a carpentry business making furniture for the last two years. His business is located in Shiatsala, a semi-urban area. He makes chairs, beds and wall units and his customers are schools and local individuals.

Kaleb's business challenges are competition from other carpenters and lack of wood due to de-forestation. He will use the proceeds of this KES 20,000 loan to buy more timber.

Kaleb is married and has four small children aged from 9 months to 5 years. In addition to his furniture business, he is a subsistence farmer. His goals in life are to be a politician and farmer and he describes himself as honest and serious in his work.

loans.use: To buy more timber

loans.name: Anonymous

loans.name: Ramadhan Akhuraua

texts.en:
Ramadhan Akhuraua M. has been running a grocery store in the village of Shiatsala near Kakamega town for the last fourteen years, and sells sugar, bread, milk and other basics to locals from the area. Ramadhan has to manage the time it takes to travel to buy new goods for his store.

He is using the proceeds of this loan to restock and also buy a battery so that he can re-charge the locals' cell phones. His long term business goal is to open another branch of his store and also to open a barber shop.

He is married to a businesswoman and they have three children, aged 6 to 14 years old. Ramadahan describes himself as a man of few words but one of action.

loans.use: To stock more groceries to sell and a battery for charging phones.

loans.name: Mbalu

This is Mbalu T.. She is 28 years old, married, and is from Waterloo. She has one child, a boy.

Mbalu has been a LAPOSL client for some time now and has taken three previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Mbalu has a small kiosk on the street in Waterloo from which she sells candies, sweets, biscuits (cookies) and other small goods. With her previous loans she expanded her business by purchasing more of the same goods for sale. With her new loan, she hopes to add more goods to her business. He goal is to pay off her loan successfully.

loans.use: To purchase more sweets, biscuits, and sugar

loans.name: Chrisanto Magori

Chrisanto Magori T., 32, sells new ladies' clothing to repeat and walk-in customers in Keroka. He has had his boutique for two years and the business challenges are decreased demand and strong competition from similar businesses.

He will be using the proceeds of his loan of 20,000 KES to buy more ladies' dresses and shoes. Chrisanto is looking forward to owning a wholesale boutique. He has two daughters and describes himself as focused and optimistic.

loans.use: To buy 15 pieces of ladies clothing.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 27 years old and married with three children. She and her husband sell groceries to make a living. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization), one of Kiva's field partners, is committed to improving lives in Nigeria.  She sells foodstuffs at retail prices. She hopes for a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Marian

Marian has been a LAPOSL client for some time now, and has taken three previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Marian sells goods (cigarettes and cookies) in the street in Waterloo town. With her previous loans she expanded her business; with her new loan she hopes to add more goods to her business.

Marian’s goal is to repay her loan successfully.

loans.name: Vida

Vida A. sells ready-made clothing for both boys and girls in Jukwa near Abura. Vida has received a commercial education (business studies, such as economics). She is single and has two children. Vida has been selling clothing for the past ten years. She is responsible for the payment of school fees and utility bills.

Her loan will be used to buy more clothes to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to invest in her children’s education.

loans.name: Cordilia

texts.en: Cordilia is 40 years old, married with 4 children. Her husband is a businessman. She is an LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She sells cooked foods and drinks. She hopes for a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She thanks all her Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en:
This is Salamatu K.. She is 30 years old, married, and is from Tombo town in Waterloo. She has two children: one girl and one boy.

Salamatu has been a LAPOSL client for some time now and has taken two previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Salamatu sells bagged rice walking in the street in Tombo town. With her previous loans she purchased an additional inventory of rice. With her new loan she hopes to add even more bags of rice to her business. She is planning to keep some of her increased profit as savings in the bank.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of rice

loans.name: Imoya

Imoya is 26 years old and is married with a husband that is a businessman. She has 1 child who does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a boutique for ladies' clothes.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim B. is married and has three children. He has received a high school education. Ibrahim sells secondhand clothes (used clothes) for men at Jukwa Market near Abura, which he has been doing for the past ten years. His wife is a trader. Ibrahim uses his income to pay school fees and utility bills. Ibrahim will use the loan to purchase secondhand clothes for sale. With the new profits from his expanded business, Ibrahim plans to invest in his children’s education and to build a house.

loans.use: Purchase secondhand clothes

loans.name: Aku

texts.fr: Cette dame est une femme courageuse et très dynamique, elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants, pour aider son époux dans les charges quotidiennes du foyer elle a débuté en 2007 le commerce de sacs de charbons de bois, elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans la ville de Sokodé. Ainsi elle arrive à réaliser de bonnes marges bénéficiaires sur ses ventes. Voulant se réapprovisionner en charbons de bois parce que son stock en baisse, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 15 sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport de cette marchandises.
texts.en:
This lady is courageous and very dynamic, she is married and is the mother of 2 children. In 2007, to help her husband with daily household expenses, she started a trade of charcoal bags that she purchases from the town of Sokode in the center of the country. She is able to make good margins on her sales. Wishing to replenish her stock of charcoal that is getting low, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to pay for the purchase of 15 bags of charcoal and their transportation.

Translated from French by caroline Mrejen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and transportation of charcoal bags for their local retail

loans.name: Zenabu

texts.en: Zenabu M. is married and has two children. She has received no formal education. Zenabu sells crates of eggs at Jukwa near the bank at Abura, which she has been doing for the past six years. Her husband is a trader. Zenabu uses her income to support her husband in paying school fees and utility bills. Zenabu will use the loan to purchase more crates of eggs for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Zenabu plans to buy a car for her business.

loans.use: Purchase crates of eggs

loans.name: Hannington Andika

texts.en: Hannington Andika O. owns O. Investments, a maize-grinding shop.  He has been in the business for thirteen years and has one employee who grinds maize into flour.  His challenges are expensive diesel and the slowness of his grinding machine.  He will be using the proceeds of KES20,000 to buy maize and some parts for the worn-out grinding machine.  He would like in the future to have three other grinding mills at Butere, Monyvlia, and Sebatia.  Hannington has a wife who is a bussinesswoman and together they have six children ranging from nine to eighteen years.  He describes himself as an honest and hardworking person.

loans.use: To buy maize and machine parts

loans.name: Komisa

texts.en:
Komisa J. is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut paste in a market and is requesting a loan to purchase beans and maize flour to sell. Komisa is 32 years old and is married with a husband who is a policeman. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase beans and maize flour

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 46 years old, married with 4 children. Her husband is a civil servant. She is an LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She sells cooked foods and drinks. She hopes for a loan amount of 60,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She thanks all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food

loans.name: Apamona

texts.en:
Apamona M. is currently in the business of selling bread and ice cream near a primary school and is requesting a loan to stock crates of sodas for sale. Apamona is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a teacher. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop near the school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy sodas for sale

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel sells groceries at retail prices to his customers in Asaba, Delta state. He is 39 years old, married with 2 children. He is an LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. His greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. He hopes to own a supermarket in the future. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase groceries

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Benkadi sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans, 5 enfants et vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Bougoula Hameau un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur sixième  prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts précédents se sont bien dénoués. 
Elles font  vente  d’huiles alimentaires, de plats alimentaires (riz préparé), des savons et des condiments alimentaires.
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 8 bidons d’huiles alimentaires, 3 sacs de 100kg de graines de riz, 12 colis de condiments alimentaires et 14 cartons de savons modernes. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent au marché de (Bougoula Hameau), à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 47.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles espèrent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  subvenir davantage aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group's seven members are primarily married women who are on average 37 years old, have an average number of five children, and mostly live in polygamous families in Bougoula Hameau. This is a village in the Sikasso municipality, the third largest administrative region of Mali. They are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance association in order to satisfy the demands of their customers, and are on their sixth consecutive loan. All previous loans have been dealt with successfully. They sell cooking oils, pre-prepared dishes (such as pre-prepared rice), soap and condiments. They would use their new loan to buy eight drums of cooking oil, three 100kg sacks of rice, twelve parcels of condiments, and 14 boxes of local soap. They source their goods from the large Sikasso town market and its neighbouring villages. They sell their goods through cash or credit sales at the Bougoula Hameau market and through home visits. Their customers are both male and female. They envisage making an average monthly profit of 47.500 FCFA; part of this would be put aside for family savings and needs, and the rest would be reinvested in business activities. The women hope to increase their capital in order to satisfy their customers and to meet the demands of their families.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina O. is married and has five children. She has received vocational training. Faustina sells towels, baby’s dresses, and secondhand clothes at Jukwa Market near Abura, which she has been doing for the past twelve years. Her husband is a farmer. Faustina uses her income to support her husband in paying school fees and utility bills. Faustina will use the loan to buy secondhand clothes for ladies for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Faustina plans to save to support her children’s education.

loans.use: Buy secondhand ladies clothes

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les huit  membres du groupe Kotognogontala sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant en moyenne  47 ans, 5 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Bougoula Hameau un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur sixième  prêt solidaire. Les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente de tasses, fruits, graines de néré, tissus, céréales (graine de riz, maïs, mil, sorgho etc), viandes etc. 
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 6 douzaines de tasses, 6 régimes de bananes, 1chargement de charrette d’oranges et de mandarines, 4 sacs de graines de néré pour faire du sounbala, 4 douzaines de complets (tissus pour hommes et femmes), 12 sacs de céréales (riz,maïs, sorgho, mil), 5 petits ruminants (pour vendre leur viande le jour de foire)  et 7paquets de condiments alimentaires.  Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Mamassoni,  de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant, en détail et  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 37.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Kotognogontala group are mainly married women with an average age of 47, and an average of five children. They generally live in polygamous families in Bougoula Hameau, a village in the Sikasso municipality, the third largest administrative region in Mali. They are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organisation in order to meet the demands of their customers, and are on their sixth loan. Their previous loans have been successfully repaid. They sell cups, fruit, néré seeds, fabric, cereals (rice, maize, millet, sorgho etc), meat etc. With their new loan they intend to buy six dozen cups, six bunches of bananas, one cartload of oranges and mandarins, four bags of néré seeds to make sounbala, four dozen suits (fabric for men or women), five small ruminants (so that the meat may be sold on market days) and seven packets of condiments. They source their goods from the Sikasso town market and from neighbouring villages, and sell their wares at the Mamassoni market, through home visits, and from their own homes. Their sales are cash- or credit-based, and their customers are both men and women. The women envisage making an average monthly profit of 37.500 FCFA each; part of this will be used for savings and family needs, and the rest reinvested in business activities.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods.

loans.name: Nelly Atieno

texts.en:
Nelly Atieno O., 31, is married and has four children ranging from the age of 4 to 13.  She runs a retail shop and sells household goods to walk-ins and frequent customers. She has been in this business for 10 years in a semi-urban area called Ugunja. Her main business challenge is the price inflation of goods.  

She is using the proceeds of her 40,000 Kenyan shillings loan to increase inventory for the upcoming holiday season. In addition, she has a motorbike for hire and a video show, where she charges viewers. In the future, she wants to be a wholesaler. Nelly describes herself as hardworking and determined.

loans.use: To buy more goods to stock

loans.name: Elisee

texts.en:
Elisee is 37 years old, married with three children ages 2,6 and 9 and he takes care of one dependent. Elisee and his family live in Gisenyi, a city in the northern province of Rwanda.  Gisenyi is on Lake Kivu and is approximately three hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.  Here, Elisee has been a proven entrepreneur working as a carpenter for the past four years. In his business, he employs 5 people who start working from 7 AM to 6 PM every day except Saturday.

Elisee is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of purchasing some additional equipment and supplies to be used in his business.  He expects that his work quality will improve with these additional items and supplies.  With this additional equipment Elisee hopes to attract more customers as well as earn more profit than previously.  With this profit, Elisee hopes that his life will change progressively as he can make more money through his efforts.  Elisee plans to continue to pay school fees and provide more food for his children. In addition to that, he will set aside some savings for their future.

loans.use: Raw materiels and supplies for carpentry

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Benkadi sont des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, 3 enfants et  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Bougoula Hameau un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur cinquième  prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts antérieurs se sont bien dénoués. 
Elles font  entre autre  la restauration, la transformation des grains de néré en Sounbala et l’achat vente  de poissons fumés, des savons, des tissus, des condiments alimentaires etc.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 3 sacs de 100kg de graines de riz en plus de 3 paquets de condiments alimentaires (pour la restauration) 2 paniers de poissons fumés,  8 cartons de savons,  2 douzaines de tissus  pour hommes et femmes, 5 sacs de 100kg de graine de néré pour le sounbala et 7 colis de condiments (pour la vente). 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent au marché de Bougoula Hameau et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 45.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Benkadi group are married women who, in average, are 38 years old and have 3 children. Most of them live in polygamous families in the hamlet of Bougoula, one of the villages of the town of Sikasso, 3rd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the needs of their customers and are applying for their fifth joint loan. All previous loans have concluded successfully. Their activities include catering, the processing of néré grains into Sounbala (traditional condiment) as well as the purchase and sale of smoked fish, soap, textiles, food condiments etc.. With this new loan, they are planning buy 3 bags of 100kg of rice with 3 packs of food condiments (for catering) 2 baskets of smoked fish, 8 cartons of soap, 2 dozens fabrics for men and women, 5 bags of 100kg of néré seed for Sounbala and 7 packages of seasonings (for sale). They buy products from markets in the town of Sikasso as well as neighboring villages. They sell their products at the market of Bougoula and at their homes, to a client base of men and women that pay in cash but also often in credit. They envision they will each make an average monthly profit of 45,500 FCFA, part of which will be used for savings and family needs, the rest being reinvested in their business.

Translated from French by caroline Mrejen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, condiments, fish, seeds, soap and fabrics for retail and catering.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John sells groceries at retail prices to his customers in Asaba, Delta state. He is 39 years old and married with four children. He is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. His greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers.  

He hopes for a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more groceries to sell. He hopes to own a supermarket in the future. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice, salt, maize flour and sugar in bulk for her restaurant.

loans.name: Sérieux Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Sérieux sont majoritairement des femmes mariées  ayant en moyenne  48 ans, 3 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Bougoula Hameau un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire. Le premier   prêt a été bien remboursé. 
Elles font entre autre la transformation, la restauration et la vente  de tissus,  de sounbala, du haricot cuisiné, des produits de beauté etc.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter,1quinzaine de tissus pour hommes et femmes, 2 sacs de 100kg de graines de néré pour faire du  sounbala, 150kg de graines de haricot ,  20 litres d’huile, 5 colis de produits de beauté, 100kg de riz, 200kg de pommes de terre et 3 paquets  de condiments pour faire la restauration.  
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent au marché de Bougoula Hameau et à domicile, au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 32.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles espèrent bien entretenir leur collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso et son partenaire Kiva afin d’améliorer leur cadre de vie.
texts.en:
The six members of the Sérieux group are mainly married women with an average age of 48, an average of three children, and generally live in polygamous families in Bougoula Hameau, a village in the Sikasso municipality- the third largest administrative region in Mali. They are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organisation in order to meet their customers' demands, and are on their second loan. The first was successfully repaid. They are involved in food processing, catering, and in the sale of fabrics, sounbala, cooked beans, and beauty products, among other things. With their new loan, they aim to buy about fifteen sheets of fabric for men and women, two 100kg bags of néré seeds for making sounbala, 150kg of bean seeds, 20 litres of oil, five parcels of beauty products, 100kg of rice, 200kg of potatoes and three packs of condiments for catering. They source their goods from the Sikasso town market and from neighbouring villages. They sell their retail ware at the Bougoula Heamu market and through home sales; they take cash or credit payments from a customer base of men and women. The women envisage making an average monthly profit of 32.500 FCFA each, a part of which would be used for savings and their families' needs, and the rest would be reinvested in business activities. They hope to maintain their collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso and its partner Kiva in order to improve their living conditions.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase various items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cosmetics inventory in bulk.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John C. renders his motorbike transport services to repeat and walk-in customers in his rural area of Shiaisala.  His business challenges are strong competition and impassable roads in bad weather.  He will use the  proceeds of the KES20,000 loan to buy riding gear and to place a downpayment on another motorbike. In the future, John wants to own ten motorbikes and have a big transport business in the Butere district.  John is married with no children and describes himself as committed and dedicated enterpreneur.

loans.use: To buy riding gear and another  motorbike.

loans.name: Sinignessigui Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Sinignessigui sont majoritairement  des femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne  32 ans, 2 enfants et qui  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Bougoula Hameau un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur quatrième  prêt solidaire. Les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente  de fruits, tissus, sounbala, chaussures, bois de chauffe, condiments alimentaires et friperies.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 5régimes de bananes, 1chargement de charrette d’orange et de mandarines, 1 vingtaine de complets (tissus pour  hommes et femmes), 4 sacs de 100kg de graine de néré pour faire du sounbala, 10 douzaines de chaussures en plastique, 1 chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 6 colis de condiments et 3 ballons de friperies.  Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent au marché de Bougoula Hameau et à domicile, au comptant, en détail et  à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles comptent sur plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  subvenir davantage aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Sinignessigui group are mainly married women with an average age of 32, an average of 2 children, and generally live in polygamous families in Bougoula Hameau, a village in the Sikasso region - the third largest administrative region in Mali. They are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organisation in order to meet their customers' demands and are on their fourth loan. All previous loans have been successfully repaid. They sell fruit, fabric, sounbala, shoes, firewood, condiments and second hand clothes. With their new loan they intend to buy five bunches of bananas, one cartload of oranges and mandarins, around twenty suits (fabric for men and women), four 100kg sacks of néré seeds for making sounbala, ten dozen plastic shoes, one truckload of firewood, six parcels of condiments and three rolls of second hand clothes. They source their goods from the Sikasso town market and neighbouring villages. They sell their retail ware at the Hameau Bougoula market and through home visits; they take cash and credit payments from a male and female customer base. The women envisage making an average monthly profit of 35,500 FCFA each; part of this would be used for savings and family needs, and the rest would be reinvested in business activities. They are counting on increased capital in order to respond to their customers' needs and to meet the needs of their families.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To open a new business, a general store.

loans.name: Eyad

texts.en:
Eyad is 37 years old. He runs a small pet store in Palestine selling aquariums, pet supplies and animal feed in the central city market. Eyad offers affordable prices and friendly service.
Eyad is requesting a loan of $3000 to purchase additional merchandise to increase his sales. He is very optimistic about the future. He plans to develop his business to achieve maximum entrepreneurial success.

loans.use: To increase his stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase items for her restaurant: rice, cooking oil, and maize flour in bulk.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Mr. Emmanuel M. is thirty-five years old; he has a retail shop dealing in leather products. He is using the loan to increase his working capital, specifically to purchase leather products for resale. He has been operating this business for over four years. The business is prospering due to the use of the loan. He hopes to be successful and more so, his future dream is to become a wholesaler of leather products in Makindye.

loans.use: To increase store inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothing in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Wakiso Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
Rebecca is a hard working lady, and at the same time, she is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is married with three children between the ages of four and eight years old, all of whom are in primary school. Rebecca also takes care of her parents and orphans. 

Rebecca has had a retail shop in Wakiso trading centre for two years, and although there is a lot of competition from other shop owners, she is able to make 50,000/= in profits. She is grateful for her previous loan from Pearl, which enabled her have more inventory, in addition to her good customer care. She also hopes to educate her children to higher levels of education. She needs a loan to help add more capital to her business for a steady supply of products to her customers.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop with more goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more soap, salt and clothing in bulk

loans.name: Yusufu

texts.en:
Yusufu is 52 years old, is married with five children, and he takes care of two dependents. His wife also sells cosmetics but they do not work together. Their children and dependents are between 7 and 26 years old.

Yusufu is a self-employed businessman who has sold cosmetics products for the past ten years. He is a proven entrepreneur with a track record of success. The hours of his business require that he works from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day except Sunday.

After having the idea of expanding his business, Yusufu is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. He will use the loan to purchase more cosmetics products which are in demand by a large number of his customers.

With this loan, Yusufu will work hard to make his business successful. If this strategy succeeds, he hopes to earn more money, which will help him to continue paying school fees for his children and dependents. In addition, he and his wife are committed to building a secure future for their family.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more used clothes in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more used clothes in bulk

loans.name: Nakalasa Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Josephine is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a divorced lady with seven children aged 25 – 9 years. She also takes care of one dependent.

Josephine is a farmer from Nakalasa and although her business is so much affected by fluctuating prices, she is able to make 40,000/= as profits. She is able to plan her seasons well and her target is to have two acres of maize per season.

Josephine also hopes to buy a plot of land so that she can enlarge her farming business. She needs a loan to help increase production by buying more seeds, pesticides and so on.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, pesticides, etc., for increased production

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en:
Titilayo sells crates of drinks in her house and has been in this business for four years. She is very happy about her business because she does not have to pay stall rent. The demand for her drinks is high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers.

Titilayo is married with four children and she is 48 years old. She is a friendly woman and she uses her friendly skill to attract more customers to her business.

Titilayo is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Titilayo is requesting a loan 100,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Leoncie

texts.en:
Leoncie is 38 years old, is married with four children, and she takes care of two dependents. Her husband works as a nurse full time and earns 80,000 RWF (approximately $140) / month. Their four children and two dependents are between 1 and 21 years old. Leoncie and her family live in Rubavu, a city in Gisenyi,in the Northern Province of Rwanda which is approximately three hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Leoncie has been making bricks for sale for the past six years. She employs four people from her community and together they work from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Leoncie is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to expand her business. She will use the loan to purchase another furnace/brick kiln so that she can satisfy her customers' growing demand for bricks. With this loan, she will attract more customers to her business and hopefully earn more profit in the process.

Leoncie will save a portion of any profits earned, as a major goal for her is to pay school fees and provide more food for her children. In addition, she will build a secure financial future for herself and her loved ones.

loans.use: To buy supplies to make more bricks and to buy another furnace/brick kiln

loans.name: Mario Octavio

texts.es: Don Mario, tiene 30 años y se encuentra casado con doña Saraitt, tienen dos hijos, que aun estan en edad escolar, viven en la casa de su mamá. La actividad principal de don Mario es la de transportista de carga con su camioneta, tiene una segunda actividad que es la de tienda de barrio, que es atendida por su esposa; precisamente para esa actividad es lo que requiere el credito, surtira la tienda con bebidas y alimentos, que son requeridos para las fiestas de fin de año.
texts.en:
Mario, age 30, is married to Saraitt and they have two children who are still of school age and live at home. Mario’s main occupation is carrying cargo with his truck; as a sideline, he has a neighborhood store, which his wife manages. The loan is to stock the store with food and beverages to cater for demand in the New Year festivities.

Translated from Spanish by John Rynne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Kitoola Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Ritah is 24 years old and is the leader of her group. She is a caterer in Kitoola. Before joining the catering business, she was a farmer and now farms on a small scale. She has offered catering services for a year now and she is grateful for her loans that have enabled her start this business.
