She tells us that her first loan was for 300 nuevos soles, which she used to buy sheep. She needs a loan of 3,000 nuevos soles to invest in the purchase of livestock (2 bulls.) Her vision of the future is to improve her business and buy more cattle. What she likes most about her communal bank is that the interest rates are low, and also the other members are punctual with their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy 2 bulls

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy rice and corn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying meal for the preparation of porridge

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay the metalworkers for the mordanting (alum-based treatment) of cotton

loans.name: Jorge Luis

texts.es:
Jorge tiene 49 años de edad, es casado y vive junto a sus dos hijos y su esposa en Puerto Malabrigo, distrito de Rázuri, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicada a tres horas y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Durante treinta años trabaja en el área de servicios de una agencia bancaria del estado. Con el fruto de sus ahorros ha instalado en su vivienda un negocio de venta de cerveza. Estas actividades le han servido para solventar los gastos familiares durante todo este tiempo.

Debido a que se aproximan las fiestas navideñas el desea ampliar su negocio por lo que se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de cervezas y gaseosas.

El es un padre responsable y que siempre busca el bienestar de su familia. Su más grande anhelo es bridarle a su hijo la oportunidad de estudiar una carrera profesional. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con nuestra Institución y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsasbilidad al momento de asumir sus pagos por lo que es considerado un cliente execelente. En la fotografía aparece trabajando en el área de servicios del banco donde trabaja.
texts.en:
Jorge is 49 years old, married, and lives with his wife and two children in Puerto Malabrigo, District of Rázuri, Ascope Province. This area is in the region of La Libertad and located 3½ hours away from the city of Chiclayo.

For 30 years, Jorge has been working in the service department for a state banking agency. With his savings, he established a home business selling beer. These activities allow him to meet his family’s expenses during this time.

Since the holidays are approaching, he wants to expand his business. For this reason, he is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 1000 soles so that he can buy beer and soft drinks.

Jorge is a responsible father who always looks out for the welfare of his family. His greatest desire is to provide his child the opportunity to study for a professional degree. He has already worked with our Institution before and has demonstrated that he is a timely and responsible with his payments. Therefore, he is considered an excellent client. The photograph shows Jorge at the banking agency where he works.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beer & soft drinks to sell during the holiday season

location.town: Puerto Malabrigo - Rázuri - Ascope - La Libertad

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy maize and rice

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
Al señor Francisco A. tiene ya más de un año dedicándose a la venta de artículos de piel (cintos, carteras bolsas etcétera).  El desea invertir en el negocio en comprar juguetes y artículos navideños, ya que sus clientes le están solicitando que tenga este tipo de cosa para la venta. 
Pero en esté momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder invertir y no quiere descapitalizar el negocio. 
Planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias que obtendrá con está nueva inversión, los gastos familiares los cubrirá con el sueldo de su trabaja en una tienda de paleas en el departamento de elaboración.
texts.en:
Sr. Francisco A. has been selling leather goods (belts, wallets, handbags, etc.) for more than a year. He wants to invest in his business by acquiring toys and Christmas items since his customers have been asking him to sell this type of merchandise. He does not have the funds at the moment to make this investment and he does not want to deplete his business of its existing capital.

He plans to repay this loan using the profits he will earn from this new investment. His family expenses are covered by the salary from his job working at a shop that manufactures shovels.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Christmas merchandise

loans.name: Jorge Oreste

texts.es:
El señor Jorge Oreste M., tiene a su cargo dos  hijos, uno de ellos se encuentran en edad escolar por lo que le debe de brindar las condicinoes necesarias para su desarrollo. Es importante destacar que ha trabajado con créditos de CEPRODEL durante 12 meses, en ese lapso ha invertido  dos créditos en la mejorar de las condiciones de su vivienda ya que ha estado en malas condiciones pero ahora ha iniciado a reconstruirla para brindarle una mejor condición de vida a sus hijos.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción para el cambio de piso de la vivienda en que habita, para así beneficiar a sus hijos a los que tanto ama.
texts.en:
Mr. Jorge Oreste M. is married and has two children, one of which is in primary school, so it is necessary he provides the necessary conditions for their development. He has worked with loans from CEPRODEL (Center for the Promotion of Local Development and Poverty Eradication) over the course of one year, during which time he has invested two loans into the improvement of his home, since it has been in bad condition. With these loans he has been able to rebuild his home to give a better living condition for his children. The loan he is requesting would be invested in the purchase of construction materials to replace the floor of the house he lives in, so it can benefit his children he loves so much.

Translated from Spanish by Joseph Mulligan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es:
El banco comunal El Despertar está formado en la ciudad de Cuenca, fue bautizada y fundada Santa Ana de los Ríos de Cuenca por los conquistadores españoles, caracterizándose por los cuatro ríos que la bañan, su centro histórico, su temperatura oscila entre 14 º a 18 º, siendo su gente muy cálida, amable y de un carisma que entregan a propios y extraños, siendo un ejemplo nuestras socias.

La Sra. María S. es socia del banco comunal El Despertar, vive por la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca en el sector de Indurama, tiene 27 años de edad y es oriunda de la ciudad de Machala, se encuentra casada y su esposo trabaja como chofer, en su unión conyugal ha procreado 1 hijo, cual tiene 11 años de edad y estudia en el Liceo Americano.
María se dedica a la venta de todo tipo de ropa, es comerciante ambulante por lo que vende recorriendo en su barrio, también vende su mercadería en la ciudad de Machala y aprovecha para realizar la compra de más mercadería, realiza esta actividad desde hace 4 años, se encuentra en su sexto ciclo y nos comenta que los prestamos le están beneficiando en el crecimiento de su negocio, tiene una bonita amistad con todas las socias del banco comunal y se caracteriza por ser una persona muy carismática, con el préstamo que la fundación le hace entrega lo va a invertir en la compra de mas mercadería, su meta es de comprarse un carro para poder viajar para traer su mercadería.
texts.en:
The community bank "El Despertar" (The Awakening) was started in the city of Cuenca, which was baptized and founded as Santa Ana de los Ríos de Cuenca by the Spanish conquistadors. It is known for the 4 rivers that surround it and its historic city center. The temperature ranges from 14ºC to 18ºC (57ºF and 64ºF). The group's members, like all citizens of Cuenca, are very warm and friendly to locals and visitors alike. María S. is a member of El Despertar community bank. She lives in the large city of Cuenca in the Indurama sector. María is 27 years old and is a native of Machala city. She is married; her husband works as a driver. They have an 11-year old son who attends the Liceo Americano (American high school). María sells clothing as a street vendor in her neighborhood. She also sells her merchandise in Machala, where she often purchases additional inventory. María has done this work for 4 years. She is in her 6th loan cycle and says that the loans are helping the growth of her business. She has a good friendship with all the members of her community bank and is known to be a very charismatic person. With this loan she will invest in the purchase of additional merchandise. Her goal is to buy a car to be able to travel further to sell her merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pants, t-shirts, blouses, children's clothing, etc.

loans.name: Ivania

texts.es:
La señora Ivania M. M.., es una joven  de 23 años de edad emprendedora de un negocio de venta de gaseosa, jugos, galletas y otros productos el cual comenzó con un capital inicial de C$5,000.00 que lo adquirió producto de ahorro hace 7 años. Este negocio está ubicado Mercado Israel lewite terminal de los buses que viajan al occidente del país 

 El crédito solicitado es para invertir en capital de trabajo del negocio; como es la compra gaseosas, jugos y galletas, que se vende mucho en esta época del año debido a las festividades de esta fecha.

Ella es casada tiene a su cargo un hijo y esta en edad escolar. Dice que antes de tener este negocio ella  Vendia ambulante en el mercado Israel lewite. 

Lleva 13 créditos en  CEPRODEL a lo largo de 5 años los cuales ha invertido en su negocio con los que ha ido creciendo, diversificando sus productos, esto gracias a los financiamientos otorgados por CEPRODEL.
texts.en:
Ms. Ivania M. M. is a young woman, 23 years of age, entrepreneur of a small business that sells soft drinks, juices, cookies and other products. She started her business with an initial capital of C$5,000.00 which were her savings of 7 years. This business is located in Israel Lewite market, the main bus station terminal for buses travelling to the west of the country.

The loan she asks for is to invest in working capital for the business, such as purchasing soft drinks, juices and cookies, of which she sells a lot in this time of the year because of the date's festivities.

She is married and has one school-age son who is dependent upon her. Before having this business she used to peddle her wares in the Israel Lewite market.

She has asked for 13 loans from CEPRODEK during the past 5 years, all of which she has invested in her business. She has expanded her business and diversified her products thanks to the loans granted by CEPRODEL.

Translated from Spanish by Cecilia Piris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory purchase: soft drinks, juices and cookies.

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhem N., 61, a local farmer who has been growing rice since 1980, is married to Rik Phan, 73, who works with her on the farm. In addition, Nhem N. sells a few fruits to her villagers for a profit. This older couple has been married for many years and is blessed with seven children, all of whom are employed at different jobs. Nhem N. now needs a loan as capital to  buy fertilizers and rice seeds to grow and a water pump for her crop. 

Note: Nhem N. was not available for the photograph, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and rice seeds to grow and a water pump for her crop

loans.name: Rezel's Group

texts.en:
Rezel P., from the village of Manaoag, Cauayan City, is the 31-year-old leader of an 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Rezel, who is married and has one school-aged child, owns and operates a general store whose income derives primarily from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Rezel has been engaged in her business for over fours years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Rezel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan, her fourth, of 10000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, and plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the store.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Renato's Group

texts.en:
Renato B. is from the village of Bungad Calamagui San Pablo, Isabela. He is 45 years old. Renato is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI, one of Kiva's field partners. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Bungad Group.

Renato is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Renato owns and operates a business raising crops. He plants and harvests corn for sale. Renato has been engaged in his business for over twenty years and earns approximately $430 every harvest season.

In 2009, Renato joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation by engaging in business activities. Renato is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Mrs. Un C., 26, is a low-income person living in Kompong Chhnang province, where she and her husband earn their income by growing rice. Un C. learned the skill of planting rice from her grandmother and used her knowledge to earn money for years. Day to day, Un C. is very busy at her farm and never wastes time. She is a good mother who tries to generate cash to be sure that both of her school-aged kids attain the highest levels of education. This is rice harvest season, and in order earn extra income, Un C. requested a loan which will allow her to order mature rice in bulk from other farmers. She will then sell it when the rice commands a high price.

Un C. was busy when the photo taken, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To order mature rice in bulk from other farmers

loans.name: Hul

texts.en: 75% of the Cambodian people make a living as farmers. One of these, Hul C. E., 38, is a hard working farmer living in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a good and determined mother who tries to feed her four children, who are all small kids. To earn a living, Hul C. E. either raises pigs or cultivates a rice crop. Her husband is a local fisherman and helps her breed pigs when he is not fishing. Hul C. E. will be using her first loan to buy farmland that will allow her to grow many kinds of crops.

loans.use: To buy farmland that will allow her to grow many kinds of crops

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en: Ouk B. is an older woman and the mother of two daughters, who are single ladies. Both of her daughters are employed: one is a garment worker and one works cooking meals for a restaurant. Ouk B. was married, but her husband died of senility. She currently walks to sell a few cakes that she produces from her home. Ouk B. is taking out her loan to repair her old house and to buy essential ingredients to make cakes for sale.

loans.use: To repair her old house and to buy essential ingredients to make cakes for sale

loans.name: Lai

texts.en:
Mrs. Lai Y., 53, and her husband Mr. Sophal Nou, 55, were married in 1976. They have seven children: three sons and four daughters. Five of the children have found full-time employment and the other two are in school. They live on an island in the Mekong River, approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Phnom Penh is the capital city of Cambodia. 

Mrs. Lai Y. has been a silk weaver since she was fourteen years old. Her husband has been a farmer for more than seven years. He grows ginger and papaya on his farm behind their house. Lai has taken one Kiva loan previously. She is now requesting another loan of $1,000 to help her husband’s farming business to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To help her husband’s farming business to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina G. is from the town of Alicia, Isabela. She is 56 years old and single. To make a living, Florentina owns and operates a business that provides hairdressing and beauty services to local community members. Florentina has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Florentina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florentina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be Florentina's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support members of her extended family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok K. S. is a teacher in the local public school and earns a salary of $90 per month. Her husband helps to support his family by working in construction. This couple has two young children who are enrolled in school. Sok K. S. said that her income is not enough to support her family’s needs. So she is requesting a loan to buy mature rice, which she will sell at a profit. This will allow her to increase her income to ensure that her family attains a better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy mature rice

loans.name: Sami

texts.en:
Mrs. Sami O., 37, and her husband Mr. Sary Chren, 42 (pictured together), live in a small village outside Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They married in 1986 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. One of their children is married and lives in his own home while the other three currently attend school. 

Sami has been a garment factory worker for almost three years, while her husband has been a construction worker for five years. Sami would like to supplement her job by starting a business to raise cows. She will be able to earn extra income by selling the cows when they grow big enough. 
 
Sami is thus requesting her first loan of US$ 600 to purchase cows to raise.

loans.use: To purchase cows to raise.

texts.en: Venus M. is from the village of Bacolod, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 57 years old, is married, and has one school-aged and three adult children. Phuong S. makes many sets of baskets before selling out. She has four school-age kids who help her weave baskets when they are not studying. Her husband (who is in the photo) also helps produce baskets with her. Phuong S. will use her loan to purchase raw materials for her basket-weaving business.

loans.name: Sotheary

texts.en:
Mrs. Sotheary T., 41, has been growing and selling flowers and longan for more than 5 years. Her husband Mr. Kunthea Un, 44, has been driving a motor taxi in Phnom Penh for more than 8 years. They live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1990 and have two sons. Their eldest son is a full-time employee in Phnom Penh and the younger son attends school.

Currently, Kunthea's business is suffering as his motorbike is old and does not work well. Thus, Sothery is requesting a loan of $1,000 to help her husband purchase a new motorbike to replace the old one and also to buy longan under contract for resale.

Mrs. Sotheary T. and Mr. Kunthea Un are in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike and longan for resale

texts.en:
Ryan A. is from the village of Gud, San Isidro. He is 23 years old. Ryan is single. To make a living, Ryan owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from motorcycle transport. Ryan has been engaged in his business for almost a year and earns approximately 300 PHP a day for these activities.

In 2009, Ryan joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ryan is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ryan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Mao C., 42, a local farmer who has been growing rice since 1990, is married to Mom Khom, 55, who works with her on the farm. This couple is married and blessed with six children, four are married and two single. Mao C. will be used her loan to buy fertilizer and seed to grow. Mao C. was busy at her farming activities, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seed to grow

loans.name: Sreysros

texts.en:
Miss. Sreysros M., 27, is single and lives with her sister and widowed mother in a small village off of National Road number Two, about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.

Sreysros has been a tailor for two years. Before this she was a garment factory worker. She is asking for her first loan of 1,100USD to purchase a sewing machine for her business and also build a restroom for the family to use.

loans.use: To purchase one more kind of sewing machine for her tailoring business and build a restroom to use in the family.

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol N. is from the town of Alimanao Peñablanca,Cagayan. She is 31 years old. Mirasol is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Mirasol is starting a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Mirasol has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 600 PHP a day for these activities.

In 2008, Mirasol joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mirasol is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Mirasol from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase manicure and pedicure supplies

loans.name: Mang

texts.en: Mrs. Mang K., 30, a local cultivator who has been growing rice since 1990, is married with two children, who attend school. Her husband appears in the picture, who works with her in planting crop. The mature rice is coming, Mrs. Mang K. needs a loan to collect to buy rice from other farmers and sell them to raise income.

loans.use: To collect to buy rice from other farmers and sell them to raise income

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en: Leonila L. is from the village of Dimaluna, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Leonila owns and operates a general store where she sells both daily-use products and ready-to-wear clothes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In July 2009, Leonila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services and to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC, which she used to purchase additional inventory. Leonila is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional inventory. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more RTW (ready-to-wear) clothes

loans.name: Kry

texts.en:
Mr. Kry Y., age 58, and his wife, Mrs. Long Hor, age 52, are farmers. They grow cucumbers. Besides farming, Kry is also a fisherman. He is applying for his first loan of $1,000 to buy cows for his farming business.

Mr. Kry Y. and his wife live along National Road No. 1 about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have nine children: four sons and five daughters. Three children are married and live outside the family home, one is a garment factory worker, and the other three are in school.

loans.use: To buy cows for his farming business

loans.name: Oem

texts.en: Oem S., 39, is a married woman and the mother of six young children. Oem S. and her husband are local rice cultivators who have been farming for many years. Besides their farm work, they also take time to produce bamboo baskets for sale. Recently, the basket material has been exhausted from their stock supply. Therefore, Oem S. needs to borrow a loan to buy more raw materials in order to weave baskets.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials in order to weave baskets.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria V. is from Dimaluna, Ozamiz City. She is 48 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Gloria owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for one year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In July 2009, Gloria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Gloria is now requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her second from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Lovelyn

texts.en:
Lovelyn B. is from Cataggaman Nuevo, Tuguegarao City. She is 47 years old. Lovelyn is married and has 2 adult children. Lovelyn owns & operates a phone retailing business. She is just starting this business.

In 2005, Lovelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Lovelyn is requesting a loan of PHP 12000, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Lovelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Cornelia

texts.en: Cornelia O. is from the town of Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. Cornelia owns and operates a business selling chicken eggs in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Cornelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. Cornelia is requesting a new loan of 2,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional feeds and vitamins for her chickens. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Van I. currently makes bamboo baskets. She is 55 years old and a resident of Kampong Chhnang province, located about 90 km from the capital city of Phnom Penh, where there are many people earn a living as basket weavers. Van I. is a widow and mother. She had been blessed with three children, two of whom are employed in the garment industry and the other one is unemployed. Van I. will use her loan to buy a cow. She will raise the cow’s offspring in the future.

loans.use: To buy a cow. She will raise its offspring in the future.

loans.name: Raisa's Group

texts.ru:
Злых Раиса – лидер данной группы. Раисе пятьдесят два года. Она с мужем работает в одном и том же месте – кафе «Этис». Он работает электриком, она же является поваром. Они вырастили одного сына, которому двадцать один год. Сейчас он учится в ВУЗе на заочном отделении. Пользуясь свободным временем, сын Раисы работает разнорабочим в частной строительной фирме в г. Бишкек. В современный век, когда мало одну профессию или работу, Раиса также решила идти в ногу со временем. Она сумела найти применение своим поварским навыкам. Да ещё и таким образом, чтобы это приносило ей материальную пользу. Она договорилась с некоторыми магазинами и кафетериями, о том, что она будет поставлять им пельмени собственного изготовления. Помимо этого, ей также удалось найти клиентов на закупку лапши для лагмана, которую Раиса также будет готовить сама. Для Раисы это дополнительное занятие явилось настоящим благом. Ведь ей не приходится ездить куда – либо. Все свои заказы она выполняет дома и поэтому эта работа её совсем не утомляет. Кроме всего прочего у Раисы не так давно были кое – какие долги. Одной зарплаты повара в кафе не хватало, чтобы разом погасить все долги. Но после того, как она начала своё дело, ей не стоило особого труда расплатиться со всеми долгами. Всего несколько часов работы по выходным приносит Раисе ежемесячно около трёх тысяч сомов. Ради таких денег, многие люди трудятся целый месяц. Сейчас Раиса решила обратиться за кредитом, чтобы закупить два мешка муки, мясо для фарша и оставшейся частью кредита оплатить контракт сына. 

У Раисы четыре партнёра по группе:

Насыкат 20 лет. Она работает барменшей в кафе. Насыйкат не замужем и живёт с родителями. Она нуждается в кредите, чтобы оплатить контракт.

Жылдыз 25 лет. Жылдыз не замужем, работает официанткой в кафе. Дома Жылдыз и её брат занимаются откормом и продажей скота. Жылдыз нужен кредит, чтобы купить двух бычков.

Ольге 52 года. Ольга работает мойщицей посуды в кафе, а также недавно открыла маленький магазин и продаёт продукты питания. Ольга хочет получить кредит и купить две тонны угля, и закупить товар для магазина. 

Турату 21 год. Он учится в политехническом университете и параллельно работает оператором на АЗС №1. Турат надеется получить кредит и оплатить контракт. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Raisa Z. is a leader of this group. She is fifty two years old. She works with her husband in the same place - cafe Etis. He works as an electrician and she is a cook. They have raised one son who is twenty one right now. At this time he is studying in university. Using his free time he works as a miscellaneous worker in a private construction company in the city of Bishkek. In today's time one profession or job is not enough and Raisa also decided to walk in foot with time. She has managed to find a good use for her cooking skills. And in a way so that it benefits her financially. She has partnered with some stores and cafes so that she will supply them with her own made "pelmeni" (dumplings with filling). Besides that she was also able to find clients to purchase noodles for lagman (a dish consisting of long noodles, meat and vegetables), which Raisa will also make herself. For Raisa this extra business has turned out to be a really good thing. Because she does not need to go anywhere. She completes all her orders from home and this is why this job does not wear her out. Besides that Raisa had a few debts. The salary of a cook in cafe alone was not enough to pay off her debts all at once. But after she has started her own business it did not take very much for her to pay off all of her debts. Only a few hours of work during the weekends brings Raisa around 3,000 soms monthly. Many people have to work a whole month for this money. Right now Raisa decided to ask for a loan to buy two bags of flour, meat for the filling and use the remainder of the loan to pay her son's tuition. Raisa has four partners in her group: Nasykat is twenty years old. She works as a bartender in a cafe. Nasykat is not married and lives with parents. She needs a loan to pay her tuition contract. Zhyldyz is 25 years old. Zhyldyz is not married and works as a waitress in a cafe. At home she and her brother feed and sell cattle. Zhyldyz needs a loan to buy two calves. Olga is 52 years old. Olga works as a dishwasher in a cafe and has also recently opened a small grocery store. Olga wants to get a loan and buy two tons of coal and merchandise for the store. Turat is 21 years old. He is studying in a polytechnic university and also works as an operator at a gas station. Turat hopes to get a loan to pay his tuition fees.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy flour and meat for dumplings and noodles, and to pay for son's education

loans.name: Soklin

texts.en:
Mrs. Soklin L., 41, and her husband Mr. Teat Ly, 42, have been married since 1991. They have two sons and one daughter, all of whom are in school. The family lives along National Road Number one, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.

Mrs. Soklin L. has been a scarf weaver since she was 18 years old, a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been a policeman since 1987. 

Soklin has requested a loan from Kiva two times previously. She now is asking for her third loan of $1,000 to purchase cotton thread materials to use in her scarf weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase cotton thread materials to use in her scarf weaving business.

loans.name: Kao

texts.en: Kao C., 59, is a hard-working man. He lives in the province of Kampong Chhnang. He currently earns his living driving a truck at the brick-field. To help with responsibility for family, his wife stays at home and sells a few groceries for a profit and also does housework. This couple has two school-aged children who are dependent on their parents’ income. Kao C. needs a loan to help purchase the inventory for his wife’s grocery business.

loans.use: To help purchase inventory for his wife’s grocery business.

loans.name: Zyinatkan's Group

texts.en:
The leader of the group Zyinatkan comes from the city of Karabalta. She has lived a simple life, raising three children. After the children grew up and left to work she still engaged herself in doing her everyday work around the house. She keeps some cattle and manages to earn a certain amount of money by selling milk.

The children have begun to make their own living. The eldest and the middle brothers are married and live separately. The youngest son, now 21, is also married. But according to Central Asian tradition, the youngest son stays with his parents to take care of them once they get old.

Life in the rural area has been more attractive to Zyinatkan than the life in a bustling city. The fresh air and everyday work of raising cattle have kept Zyinatkan young. She loves the way she lives and enjoys every day of her life. Now that her son is by her side and helps look after the cattle, her life is even easier.

Selling milk brings Zyinatkan about $70 a month. Because of this money, Zyinatkan has been able to make some repairs at home. One thing that concerns Zyinatkan is the winter season. They need coal to get through it. Zyinatkan has applied for this loan to purchase a sufficient amount of coal. Zyinatkan’s partners are: Ainur, 45, keeps cattle and sells milk. Her husband helps Ainur around the house. They have five children: four daughters and one son. Two daughters live separately. Ainur needs a loan to prepare a dowry for their third daughter. Farida, 44, and her husband are raising four children. They keep cattle and farm. They make their living by selling milk and onions that they grew. Farida needs a loan to make a repair at her house. Her goal is to give all her children a good education. Mirbek, 21, is single. He is already making his own living. He has a trailer and offers transportation services. Besides that, he raises livestock and sells milk. Mirbek needs a loan to buy fuel for sowing. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy coal for the winter season

loans.name: Agnes' Group

texts.en:
Agnes M. is from the village of District 1, Cauayan City. She is 26 years old. Agnes is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by the Kiva field partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Agnes is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Agnes owns and operates a business selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Agnes has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $43 a month from this activity.

In 2007, Agnes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Agnes is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
Mrs. Sina S., 24, and her husband, Mr. Sokhorn Khan, 27, were married in 2002 and have two young sons. She lives with her parents in a small village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sina sells desserts in front of her house. In the past, she was a garment factory worker. Her husband is a motor remoque taxi driver. A remoque is a motorbike with a trailer attached at the back. He carries goods and people from his village to Takhmao market and back. However, his motorbike is old and breaks down, which upsets his business. 

Sina is asking for a loan of $600 to buy a new motorbike for her husband to replace the old one.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for her husband to replace the old one.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim S., age 61, is a local farmer who lives alone in her small wooden house located in Kampong Chhnang province. She sells porridge for breakfast to her nearby neighbors in the village. She was married, but her husband died of senility. She has two daughters who are working in Thailand. Kim S. hopes to earn additional income by using a Kiva loan to buy piglets to raise at her home.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise at her home

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites V. is from the village of Gud, San Isidro. She is 26 years old and married with one infant child. To make a living, Marites raises pigs to sell. She has been engaged in her business for a year now and earns approximately $75 whenever she sells her animals.

In 2009, Marites joined the Kiva field partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Marites is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

Geraldine M. is from the town of Alimanao Peñablanca,Cagayan. She is 36 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Geraldine makes and sells food, primarily barbecues to the local community.  Geraldine has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

loans.name: Yon

texts.en:
Yon U., 24 (husband pictured), is a local rice farmer.  She's been a skilled planter for years.  Beside farming, she also works in the garment factory to make some extra income. Yon U. is married and has two young school-aged children.  Her husband also cultivates a rice crop. 

Yon requests a loan to buy rice in bulk to store away. She will sell the rice when it commands a highest price. Yon was busy working all day, so her husband is pictured.

loans.use: Buy rice in bulk to resell.

loans.name: Saroem

texts.en:
Saroem C., 63, is a widow with two sons and one daughter. One is married and lives outside the family home and the others assist their mother in her business. They live in a small village along National Road Number Two, about 13 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Saroem sells food: porridge and soup in front of her house and has done so for more than 10 years.  She is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase additional materials such as tables, chairs, dishes, spoons and so on.  It will be easier for her to operate her business, as well as more lucrative, when she has enough materials.

loans.use: Purchase additional materials to operate her business.

loans.name: Uch

texts.en: Uch S., 40, is a local basket weaver who learned the trade from her grandmother.  She also sells baskets that she gets from her husband's production, or buys from other weavers. The family lives with two children who are already enrolled in public school. Uch S. is asking for a loan to buy baskets from other weavers in order to meet the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To buy baskets from other weavers in order to meet the needs of her customers

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline C. is from the city of Caritan Norte Tug. She is 39 years old. Evangeline is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline owns and operates a business venture providing waste management services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating tricycle transport services. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Evangeline joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP, which will be used to pay for registration, franchise, and license fees. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Evangeline from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Leonor

texts.en:
Leonor G., pictured on the far right making a sale, is from the village of Matugas Bajo, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children.

Leonor owns and operates a snack-vending business, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Leonor joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale.

Leonor is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Phoem

texts.en:
Mr. PhO. O., 51, and his wife Mrs. Kimlib Kol, 49, have been married for more than 20 years. They have two daughters: one is a garment factory worker while the other one attends university. The family lives outside of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. His wife is shown in the photo.

PhO. is a policeman. His wife stays at home and does housework. In the past, she would sell rice pork. PhO. is asking for a loan of $800 to pay the school fee for his daughter, who is in the last year of her bachelor's degree in Accounting.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his daughter.

loans.name: Amara

texts.en:
Mr. Amara C., 27, is single and lives with his siblings and parents (his mother is pictured) along National Road number one about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Mr. Amara C. has been a construction contractor for 7 years. He does not have enough materials to operate his business, so he is asking for his first loan of $1,200 to purchase additional construction materials for his business.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for his business.

loans.name: Thol

texts.en:
Thol S., 24, is the young mother of a lovely baby. She currently works sewing clothes in the garment factory and also cares for her child or does housework when she is not working. She is married to Choun Kosal, age 25, a security guard at a company.

Thol S. has faced difficulties with transportation to her work place. She has rented a taxi or walked to work, because she doesn’t have a vehicle for riding purposes. To solve the problem, Thol S. decided to seek a loan of US$1200 to buy a new motorcycle to ride to work.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle to ride to work

loans.name: Vuth

texts.en:
Mrs. Vuth M. (in the photo), 47, and her husband Mr. Mao Koy, 48, were married in 1983 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. Three of them are garment factory workers, one attends school, and the other one is still young. They live in a small village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Vuth and her husband have been fishing for more than 20 years. In addition, Mr. Mao Koy is a construction worker. He works in his village and other districts. Vuth is asking for a loan of $1,100 to buy a motorbike for her children to drive to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to drive to work.

loans.name: Sarong

texts.en:
Sarong C., 48, and her husband Cheung Brach, 46, live in a small village along the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1988 and have six children: two sons and four daughters. Four attend school.    

Sarong has been a silk weaver for 30 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who sells them in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a house builder for 10 years. 

Sarong is requesting her first loan of $500 to purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business. She will also use a part of her loan to repair her house.

loans.use: Purchase silk for weaving business and repair home.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Mrs. Veronica S. is from the village of Bacolod, Ozamiz City. She is 36 years old, is married, and has one infant and two school-aged children. Veronica owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store selling home products. She has been engaged in her business for three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2009, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Veronica is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products for her retail store. This loan will be her first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family and to save for future emergencies. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. loans.name: Pedra's Group

texts.en:
Pedra I. is from the town of Guba, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children.

Pedra owns and operates a business providing a jeep, the Filipino version of a bus, for transportation to local community member. She inherited the jeep from her mother-in-law, Evangeline, who passed away but still holds the jeep's operating license in her name for the next three years(as pictured). Pedra will transfer the license and name of the jeep to herself after the three years. Pedra has been engaged in this business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Pedra joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC.

Pedra is requesting a new loan of 14,800 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be her second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.name: Rosavic

texts.en:
Rosavic is a single 35-year-old entrepreneur trying to earn income to help her family with their daily needs and to save for her future. She lives in the village of Brgy Alejandria, La Carlota City, Negros Occidental.

Rosavic joined the Kiva field partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in October 2003 in order to open her own business. Upon receiving her first loan, she started a fish-vending and ready-to-wear (RTW) business so she could help her parents. Unfortunately, her fish-vending business lasted for for only two years.

When she received her 6th cycle loan, she invested in a pig-fattening business and added it to her RTW business. With succeeding loans, her businesses got bigger and earned good money. She also invested in frozen products for additional income. She is able to earn about $152 a month at a minimum. She saves most of her income for the future and for her family.

With the utilization of her previous loan of 7,000 PHP to buy frozen products, Rosavic was able pay in full and on time without any delay, giving her recognition as a good performing member by maintaining her good credit record to the center and to NWTF-PD. At present, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP, which will be used as additional working capital for her pig-fattening business.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her pig-fattening business

About BRAC:
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

Now requesting a loan of 4000 PHP, her first, to be used in the food sector, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her enterprise.

texts.en:
Bun T., age 31, owns a grocery store in front of her home, where she sells various kinds of cooking ingredients to earn a living. Bun T. has been in this business since the beginning of 2000 and is earning around US$ 5 each day. She is married to Seng Hun, 36, who is an electrician for a ministry.

Bun T. has conducted her business very well and gained many customers and income. Recently, part of her inventory has sold out and she lacks money to resupply her stock. Therefore, Bun T. requests a loan of US$ 400 which she will use to buy additional grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Vitaliana

texts.en:
Dealing in native products made from rattan like baskets or “bukag”, “oway”, hand fans, rattan balls for "sipak takraw", native brooms and "abacca" rope is a tough business for a widow with four children like Mrs. Vitaliana A.. She is 50 years of age, living in Barangay III, Tangub City. She has a daughter who works in Jordan and helps her with her financial problems. The rest of her children are school-age.

Vitaliana has been running this kind of business for 2 years, beginning with a starting capital of P1,500. She earns a net income of P2,000 per month. In the year 2008, she became a member of PAGLAUM MPC and was able to access a first loan amounting to P3,000. With a good credit record, she has been given the privilege of accessing the amount of P5,000 to add to her capital in her existing business due to the growing demand of her loyal customers and friends. The future income from her loan will be used to meet their basic needs and as savings for her children.

loans.use: Additional capital for her native products (rattan goods) sales business

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Mrs. Yolanda C., 30 years of age, is the wife of Rolando C., an electrician. Her husband is the one who assembles the video game machines and videoke (amateur singing to a recorded music video background) machines and sells them to their customers.

Yolanda and Rolando are now living happily in Barangay III, Tangub City and are blessed with three children all of whom are now of school age.

The couple has run this video game and videoke machine-assembly business for already ten years. From the average of two units being assembled and sold, they are earning an average net income of P6,000 a month. With eight units of videoke machine and several video game machines operating in the city, they are also receiving an average share from all these units of not less than P5,000 every 15th and 30th day of the month.

Just this year, Yolanda joined Paglaum MPC because she is interested in our programs and services. With a good character and with capacity, she was given the privilege of obtaining a loan of P50,000 with the purpose of purchasing additional parts and accessories to assemble new video game units and to recondition all other old units for sale.

The future profits from this loan will be used to save for their children’s future and for their daily needs. The couple plans to expand their business to other cities and nearby municipalities.

loans.use: To purchase accessories amd parts for video game and videoke machine assembly

loans.name: Nhoeum

texts.en:
Nhoeum K. is a 41-year-old married woman who currently resides in the middle of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She sells fish and vegetables in the market. She started selling more than eight years ago. 

Nhoeum K. is blessed with three children. One of her daughters works in the garment factory, while the other two attend school. Her husband is a fisherman and also a construction worker. 

Nhoeum K. requested a loan of $1,000 for her husband to use as capital to buy more gear for fishing and to buy small fish to raise. She and her husband are pictured here.

loans.use: To buy more gear for fishing and to buy small fish to raise

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en: Ma. Fe O. lives in Masville Cubay, La Carlota City, Negros Occidental. She is 34 years old and married. Her husband has operated their watch-repair business for the past 29 years in the city proper of La Carlota. The couple is blessed with five children, ages 5 to 16 years old. Ma. Fe started from nothing. They live in a very dilapidated house because her husband's income cannot support the total needs of the family. She worried about the future and what would happen if her children started going to school. Thus, she invested in a pig-fattening business that can also help in defraying family expenses. She continued her business until such time that she could expand it. In 2004, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon for the said purpose of expanding the businesses, especially the pig-fattening business. She was able to improve her business by buying additional pigs for fattening. With one sow to raise, she has used some of her loan as additional capital for her watch-repair business. She was able to earn a minimum of 3,600 Philippine pesos per month. She saves most of her income for the education of her children. Ma. Fe joined NWTF-Project Dungganon so she could have her own business and to help her husband for her children's future because she wants all of them to finish their studies and get good jobs. Ma. Fe's previous loan of Php 15,000 was utilized for the pig-fattening business and was fully paid on time and in full without delay. With her 10th loan, she will use Php 18,000 as additional working capital for her business. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her pig-fattening business

texts.en:
She is a widow with two children: one is a policeman serving in Iligan City and the other is a college student. Mrs. Glenita M., 50 years of age, is a resident of P1 Silanga, Tangub City. As the sole breadwinner of the family, she employs herself by focusing on her sari-sari (variety) store business and is able to provide for her children’s needs.

Glenita  started her sari-sari store business eleven years ago with a starting capital of only P1,500. Now, she earns an average net income of P3,000 per month.

In 2008, Glenita joined Paglaum MPC because she was much interested in our programs and services. She was able to obtain her first loan of P5,000 and, with a good credit record, she was able to obtain multiple loans. This time, she is given the privilege of obtaining P6,000 to extend her sari-sari store and to add to her capital for purchasing the goods she needs for her business.

The future income from this loan will be used to support Glenita’s college student child and for her savings for the future needs of her family.

texts.en: Lach P. is a humble villager living in the rural area of Phnom Penh, where she owns farmland that she plants with different kinds of crops to earn a living. Her husband works with her on the farm and also raises cows. This couple has a daughter and two sons. Both of their sons are construction workers and contribute their income for the family’s daily expenses. Lach P. always finds it hard to travel because she has no vehicle for transportation. She would like a loan from Kiva which will allow her to buy a used motorcycle for her family's transportation.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores is a 29-year-old mother with two young children, ages 4 and 7. She works hard to help her husband meet the needs of their children, especially their education, and to improve their family's living conditions. Dolores lives in the village of Brgy Paraiso, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. Her husband, Walter, works as a laborer in a Hacienda (sugarcane plantation). The money he earns is not enough to sustain the needs of their family, especially their children.

Because Dolores has knowledge about running a business, she would think of ways to begin and what kind of business she could invest in. This also encouraged her to join NWTF-Project Dungganon in the year 2002 in order to have start-up capital for her proposed business.

With the capital to invest in a general store, she bought different items to sell. Loans continued, and she was able to add a food-vending business and a pig-fattening business. She knows that this can help her earn money and realize her dreams. She was able to earn a minimum of $43 a month and saved most of it for her children.

Her previous loan of 17,000 PHP was used as working capital for her business. That amount was returned to NWTF-PD in full and on-time without any delay. She is currently on her 13th cycle loan, requesting 19,000 PHP, which will be used to buy additional items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz E. lives in the village of Prk Tan-ao, Brgy Lopez Jaena, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She is 60 years old. She works and earns for the day-to-day living costs of her family. She is married and blessed with four adult children aged from 30 to 37 years old. Luz wants to secure her future when she is older and still be able to help her grandchildren finish their studies.

Years ago, Luz wanted to earn extra money to help her husband and to send the children to school. Because she lived in a hacienda, a sugarcane plantation, she thought that a general store would be a very convenient business to put up in their area - different items sold at an affordable price and the fastest turnover of capital and income. She invested in a small store to reach her goal of helping her husband. The income from her business was allocated for education, family expenses and additional capital. Business ran smoothly and she was able to expand it. In 1995 she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to expand her business and to buy additional products to sell. With more capital, her loans had a big impact on her business because she was able to earn more compared to her previous earnings. Her general store supplies the needs of the hacienda employees which is payable at the end of each week. She earns a minimum of Php 4,000 a month. She saves most of her income for her future and for her grandchildren.

Luz's previous loan of Php 19,000 was used as additional capital for her general store. The said amount was paid every week and fully paid within her loan term without any delay. Her 18th cycle loan of the same amount of Php 19,000 will be used as additional working capital. Income from it will be used for her grandchildren's education.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project <i>Dungganon</i> (a Hiligaynon word that means <u>Honorable</u>). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them <i>Dungganon</i> - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her general store

Rit P. thinks that it is the time when he could earn additional income, so he is requesting a loan for capital so he can order rice in bulk to store in his home. He will sell it to gain income when the rice commands a high price.

loans.name: Tsetsegdari

texts.en:
P. Tsetsegdari is 46 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Gobi-Altai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her husband currently works as a welder for repairing metal goods and machinery parts, and both her son and daughter are university students. Tsetsegdari operates a dairy and raw material trading business in her town. She started her business in 1996 selling only raw materials. After growing her business and stabilizing her income, she expanded to selling dairy products in 2007. Tsetsegdari is a very hardworking businesswoman who is focused on achieving her goals. She says, "I will be happy if I can give my children a good and happy life." She is requesting a 1,600,000 tugrug loan to purchase dairy products to sell in her business.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.name: Aimshiggui

texts.en:
B. Aimshiggui is 32 years old and lives with his wife and sons in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger". His oldest two sons currently attend a local secondary school and his youngest hasn't yet reached school age. Aimshiggui operates a second-hand clothing business in his town. He purchases second-hand clothing items from Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's largest city and capital, twice a month and transports them back to his province to sell. Aimshiggui started his business in 2002 by selling a variety of second-hand clothing items. He has successfully grown his business over the years and has gained much business experience. Today, his business continues to grow quickly and he now only sells women's clothing and shoes, which are his most demanded and profitable items. Aimshiggui hopes to continue to maintain his business successfully. He says, "I want to save enough money to support my children's education." He is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug (~2814 USD) loan to purchase second-hand clothing for his business. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

loans.name: Patria

texts.en:
Mrs. Patria C., 48 years of age, married but separated from her husband, is a resident of Sumirap, Tangub City. She is currently engaged in operating a sari-sari (variety) store along the National Highway.

Patria has two children and both are now of school age. Being separated from her husband is not easy for her but she faced life’s challenge together with her live-in partner who is a driver.

For seven years, Patria was able to sustain her business and now she is earning an average net income of not less than P3,500 a month. She joined Paglaum MPC two years ago because she is very much interested in our products and services and for our being one of the most outstanding cooperative in Northern Mindanao and the awarded coop for being “Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines” during the search for COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006.

With a good credit record, Patria was able to obtain multiple loans. Now, she is given the privilege of obtaining her 4th loan in the amount of P25,000 with a project proposal of purchasing a secondhand motor cab to be attached to their newly acquired motorcycle to make it a passenger cab for hire. The remainder of the loan will be used to add to the capital of her sari-sari store business.

The future income will be used for Patria’s loan repayments and as savings for the future, especially for emergencies.

loans.use: To purchase a secondhand motor cab and to purchase stock for her store

loans.name: Bayasgalan

texts.en:
R. Bayasgalan is 46 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in Uvurkhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian tent called a "ger." His oldest two sons currently help with the family business and his youngest is in high school. Bayasgalan operates a transport service and raw materials trading business in his town. He transports goods and supplies for people from his province to Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. Sometimes he purchases coal and firewood from local suppliers in order to sell it to residents in the city. Bayasgalan started his business in 2003 and has made much progress over the years. His business is growing fast and he is thankful he has his sons to help him keep up with growing demand. Bayasgalan is a very open-minded person who has good communication skills. He is focused on the continued success of his business and says, "With my business earnings I want to open a grocery shop in my town." He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase firewood to sell.

About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. loans.name: Dorjhand

texts.en:
S. Dorjhand is 64 years old and lives with her husband in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She lives in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Dorjihand operates a door-to-door meal service in her town. She prepares a variety of different meals at her home and delivers them directly to her customers. She has a loyal customer base consisting mainly of people working at various local businesses. They appreciate her convenient service. 

Dorjhand started her business in 2000 with capital of 20,000 tugrugs (~14 USD). She has been very successful over the years and works hard to attract new customers. Today, her working capital exceeds 400,000 tugrugs (~280 USD). Dorjhand is looking toward the future and is always looking for ways to improve and expand her business. She is requesting a 400,000 tugrug (~280 USD) loan to purchase food and grocery items for her business.


About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
