loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose C. is a 35-year-old married woman with six children. Her husband is a carpenter, and her children attend school. To earn a living, she sells bread and sugar out of a shop. Now, she is requesting a loan to purchase other items, such as beans, rice, maize, and flour for re-sale purposes. With the extra income generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to alleviating poverty and empowering the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services. Such services are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs, as measured by the scale and diversity of its activities. In 2007, BRAC commenced operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations and includes more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional goods (e.g., beans, rice, maize, and flour)

loans.name: Norieta

texts.en:
Norieta M. is a 41-year-old married woman with four adult-age children from the village of Rizal. To earn a living, Norieta owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector; specifically, she operates a clothing business and a cosmetics sales business. Her primary income is generated by providing general clothing services to local community members. Norieta has been engaged in her business for over two years, and she typically earns approximately 3,500 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Norieta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. As a result, she was able to both improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Norieta is requesting a loan in the amount of 4,000 PHP ($100), which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This loan would be the first loan taken out by Norieta from ASKI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated by the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. Indeed, it has 25 branches, covering the Central and Northeastern areas of the country. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen/women, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Galbaatar

texts.en:
B. Galbaatar is 49 years old, and lives with his wife and two children in Gobi-Altai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent, which is called a "ger." Both of his children (a son and a daughter) attend university.

To earn a living, Galbaatar, with his wife's help, operates a firewood and coal-trading business in his town. They use their own truck to transport the coal and firewood, and they rent a small stall from which they sell their products. Galbaatar started his business in 2004 with a loan of 500,000 MNT (~$350) from Xacbank, Kiva's Mongolian MFI partner. Over the years, his business has been quite successful, and he has proven himself to be a trustworthy borrower. Galbaatar is focused on the future; in particular, he hopes to generate additional income so that he can pay for his children's tuition. He is now requesting a loan in the amount of 4,000,000 MNT (~$2,750) to purchase another truck to use for his business.

About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first Kiva loan in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale, and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers in the form of a savings account upon the maturity of their loans. By doing so, XacBank not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team at http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia. And to lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.phppage=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon.

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing another truck

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

Elsa is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Elsa owns and operates a general store, selling products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

Elsa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Elsa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for the tuition fees of her children.

Frashiah is the woman in the centre of the photo above.

loans.name: Nde

texts.en:
E. is married with five children. She and her family live in Ntassen, Cameroon, in a house with seven rooms.

E. has had to overcome some challenges in life, such as ill health, difficulty paying her children's school fees, the death of her father, and persistent increases in the price of basic commodities. She farms and sells firewood in order to earn a living.

This will be E.'s eighth time receiving a loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2000 and has been quite successful in the past, due to her business's location and reasonable prices. With her experience, she now has good yield from her pig farming and firewood businesses.
 
Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children, buy necessities for the family, and give them good medication when they are sick. Part will be ploughed back into her provision store.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying of rice, savon, oil, groundnuts

loans.name: Jambaa

texts.en:
L. Jambaa is 24 years old and lives with her parents in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger". Jambaa operates a computer and printing services business in her town. She provides a variety of computer services such as document typing and copying as well as large sign and banner printing. She provides some services on-site but mainly takes orders from local residents and businesses and sends them to a company in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, to be completed. Jambaa started her business in 2009 by renting a stall at a local trading center to conduct her business. Although she doesn't have all of the equipment necessary to print large signs and bannars, her business has grown quickly since she opened earlier this year. She says, "I am planning to expand and improve my business and want to have my own working place in the future so that I can complete all of my services on site." She is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug (~2800 USD) loan to purchase printing supplies and equipment for her business.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: to purchase printing supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.name: Lhagvajav

texts.en:
T. Lhagvajav is 46 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". Her oldest son is a university student and her youngest son and daughter attend a local secondary school. She opeartes a coal and firewood trading business with the help of her husband in her town. She also works as a teacher at a local secondary school. Lhagvajav's husband is mainly responsible for purchasing and selling the coal and firewood as she is busy teaching most days. She manages the financials of the business and advises her husband on the day to day operations. They purchase coal and firewood twice a month and use their truck to transport the goods. Lhagvajav started the raw materials business in 2007 and has had much success over the last two years. She says, "My husband and I are working hard to save money for our childrens' education. In the future I would like to open my own store." She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan to purchase coal for her business and to pay some medical expenses for her children. At the picture: Lhagvajav and her husband.


About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: to purchase coal for her business and to pay some medical expenses for her children

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud has owned a library in his town since 2001 where he provides books, binding and photocopying services to the villages’ students. He's 36 years old with 2 children. Mahmoud is asking to borrow $1,200 to purchase stationery and appliances for his library in order to increase his business productivity.

loans.use: to purchase stationery and appliances

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en: Happiness is 43 years old and she is married with 5 children. Happiness is a hard working woman and she is determined to excel in her business and family life. She sells plantain and yam at the front of her house. She sells for long hours to provide the food on her table to feed her family.She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. Happiness is requesting for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more plantain and yam to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more plantain and yam  to sell

loans.name: Oyungerel

texts.en:
Z. Oyungerel is 42 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Gobi-Altai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her sons, ages 20 and 19, are both university students. Oyngerel operates a grocery and dairy trading business with the help of her husband. She operates her business from a rented stall and sells a variety of food and local dairy products. Oyungerel started her business in 2000 with a loan of 300,000 tugrugs (~210 USD) from Xacbank, Kiva's Mongolian MFI. Her business has grown quickly over the years and she has gained much business experience. Her earnings have enabled her to buy a car for her family and rent an additional stall at a local trading center. Oyungerel is focused on continuing her success in the future and says, "I am working hard to support my family and raise my children to be responsible people." She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan to purchase vegetables to sell in her business. 


About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: to purchase vegetables to sell

loans.name: Gideon

texts.en: Gideon, who is 40 years old and married with three school-age children, runs Gideon Electronics and sells various electronic accessories. He has been in business for four years and is requesting this loan from Faulu for Kes. 50,000 to increase his inventory of accessories.   Describing himself as optimistic and hardworking, Gideon says that in Faulu he has learned how to save money. In the future, he hopes to improve his standard of living by expanding his business into wholesale supply and purchasing a pick-up truck to use for transportation.

loans.use: To buy a stock of electronic accessories.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: Hasan, a 27-year-old single man, works as a farmer where he produces dairy products for sales. He has been involved in this field since 2006. Today, Hasan is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase fertilizers and seeding for his business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeding

loans.name: Tsend-Ayush

texts.en:
Tsend-Ayush T. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in Arkhangai Province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger." Her two oldest sons attend university and her youngest is in high school. Tsend-Ayush opeartes a mobile clothing trading business with the help of her husband in her town. She started her business in 2000 with capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD) and quickly grew it to a stable operation. She continues to build on her experience and attributes her success to her good accounting skills. Today, her working capital exceeds 2,00,000 tugrugs (~1400 USD) and she has many loyal customers. Tsend-Ayush is looking toward the future and says, "I want to expand and improve my business." She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan to purchase clothes to sell in her business.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Lucrecia

texts.en:
Lucrecia M. is from the village of Santa Rosa, Gamu,Isabela. She is 40 years old. Lucrecia is married and has children. To make a living, Lucrecia owns & operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products to the local community. Lucrecia earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Lucrecia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Lucrecia is requesting a loan of 40000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Lucrecia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel sells handbags at retail prices in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is 39 years old, married, and has 5 children. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Mabel is requesting for a loan in the amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more handbags to sell. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more second hand handbags to sell.

loans.name: Sénévé Plus Group

texts.en: Sénévé Plus is a Community Bank made up of 25 micro entrepreneurs whose chairwoman is Getou M.. These members are united for the same goal. They wish to grow their businesses by loans received from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC. Getou sells soft drinks in her area, located in the northeastern area of Kinshasa. She began her business in 2002 with initial capital of $80.00. After hard work and good management, she has succeeded in making her business thrive, thanks to the accumulated profits. She is a loyal client of IMF HOPE RDC and she has already received four different loans. These previous loans have been fully repaid. She intends to reinforce her capital with the next loan by adding five crates of soft drinks. This business gives Getou a profit of $60.00 every week. Getou is 42 years old, single and the mother of a 17-year-old daughter who attends school.

loans.use: To purchase five crates of soft drinks.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Melecia

texts.en:
Melecia D. V. is from the village of Ramos East. She is 23 years old. Melecia is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Melecia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector selling cosmetic products. Melecia earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melecia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Melecia is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP. This will be the first loan taken out by Melecia from ASKI. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Towards additional capital for business.

loans.name: Bader

texts.en: Bader is an 18-year-old single man. In 2007, he opened a phone repair shop to begin a new career and to make an income. His work includes changing phone accessories and he performs maintenance on broken phones. Today, Bader is asking for a loan of $1,200 to purchase phone accessories and tools to repair phones, in order to satisfy the demands of his clients.

loans.use: To buy phone accessories and phone maintenance tools.

loans.name: Vilma Cardona Group

texts.en:
Vilma C., from the village of Buena Suerte, Cauayan City, Isabela, is the 41-year-old leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Vilma, who is married and has 2 school-aged children, owns and operates a general store whose income derives primarily from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Vilma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vilma is requesting a new loan, her third, of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ferdinand's Group

texts.en: Ferdinand V. is from the village of Alinam, Cauayan City. He is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Ferdinand is 42 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. He owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately 20,000 every harvesting season. In 2008, Ferdinand joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be his fourth from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Sarepta Plus Group

texts.en:
José K. is a leader of a community bank named “Sarepta Plus”, which is composed of 31 microentrepreneurs.
José K., aged 30, is single. He runs a clothing boutique in the north eastern area of Kinshasa and has been in business since 2004. José has acquired solid experience and his business has prospered thanks to good management and accumulated profits. He intends to use the next loan to purchase women’s clothing and shirts to increase the inventory of his business. Currently, he earns a profit of $60 every week.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for resale

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel O. is 39 years old and happily married with 2 children. She is a hardworking woman. Mabel sells sarongs and lace at the market in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. Mabel is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Mabel is requesting  a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs  to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George N. is from  Linao Norte Tuguegarao, City. He is 32 years old. George is married and has an infant child. To make a living, George operates a family member's business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business.The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing mechanical services to local community members. George has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

George joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. George is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by George from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in his business

loans.name: Gloire Plus Group

texts.en:
Gloire Plus is a group of owners of small businesses chaired by Madeleine. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva through the MFI (Micro-Finance Institution) HOPE DRC to grow their businesses.
Madeleine K. is determined to be a successful businesswoman. She sells bananas and peanuts. She became a micro-entrepreneur in 1994. Madeleine has received five loans from the microfinance Institution HOPE DRC and fully repaid them. She intends to use this loan to expand her inventory. She will buy three heads of bananas and a sack of peanuts for resale in order to reinforce her working capital and increase the profit. Currently she earns a profit of $30 a week. She will seek to make more profit by delivering more bananas. Madeleine is 55years old, married and the mother of eight children aged 15 to 32.

loans.use: To purchase three heads of bananas and a sack of peanuts for resale in order to increase profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Fridah

texts.en:
Fridah M. is 25 years old and has a business selling clothes and cosmetics. She has been in business for two years and mostly sells to urban customers. She is requesting Kes. 20,000 to increase her inventory. 

Fridah says that as a member of Faulu Kenya she has learned how to manage her business more professionally. She describes herself as  hardworking and would like to expand her business into a combined beauty shop and boutique.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable micro-finance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A. is 56 years old and happily married with 2 children. She is a hardworking woman. She is a LAPO client. She sells foodstuffs at the market in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria.  Elizabeth is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs  to sell

loans.name: Bikamwa Plus Group

texts.en:
Yvon P., age 44, is the leader of the “Bikamwa Plus” community bank, which is composed of 28 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through HOPE RDC to develop their businesses. Yvon is married and has three children between 1 and 11 years old. Only one goes to school.

Yvon started his business in 1990 with $50 of initial capital. He manages his business in the western part of Kinshasa. He is a loyal client of HOPE RDC who has already received four different loans and has repaid them properly. He intends to use the next loan to buy three 25 kgs/cartons of meat to resell so he can increase his profits. Each day, his business brings in a profit of $5. 

His ambition is to open a cold storage facility.

loans.use: To purchase three 25 kgs/cartons of meat to resell

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 33-year-old married mother of four children, two boys and two girls. For two years, she has run a butcher shop where she sells meat wholesale. She previously sold shoes. She is now requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to increase her stock of meat. 

Jane describes herself as hardworking, disciplined, and committed, and hopes to operate a larger business in the future by becoming a major meat distributor. She says that, in Faulu,she has learned to manage her business better.

loans.use: Add to her meat inventory

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en:
Sunday S. sells charcoal and groundnut paste. She is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal and groundnuts to sell. Sunday is 30 years old and is widowed. She has 7 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a "hotel" (typically, a food stall or tiny restaurant; not a sleeping lodge).

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal and groundnuts

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy sells used clothes and natural medicine to her customers at retail prices. She lives Warri, Delta State. She is 35 years old and married, and she has 2 children.. She is a hard-working woman. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family members. She is hoping for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more natural medicines to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more natural medicines to sell

loans.name: Keji

Keji F. sells charcoal and beans in the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. Keji is 28 years old and is married. Her husband is a tailor. She has 3 childrenwho go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina A. sells used clothes in the market and is requesting a loan to buy clothes in bulk to sell.  Sabina is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 2 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a big shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy clothes in bulk to sell

loans.name: Shogher

texts.en:
Shogher D. lives in Aghavnavank Village in the Ijevan area. She is a widow and has 3 daughters. Two of her daughters are married and live independently and the third one is engaged. 

Shogher works as a librarian in the village administration building. She also raises cattle and manages a little food and household goods shop (you can see it in the photo) which is located in her home. Cattle breeding is very hard and profitable work which helps Shogher to finance her family and organize her daughters’ weddings. 

Shogher needs a 600.000 AMD loan to buy fodder for her farm animals, to buy 4 or 5 pigs for her farm, and to buy candy and juice for her shop to sell during the New Year’s holidays.

loans.use: To buy fodder for her farm animals, to buy 4 or 5 pigs for her farm, and to buy candy and juice for her shop

loans.name: Agustin

texts.es:
El señor Agustín  tiene 62 años de edad, cuenta con un taller de herrería de hace mas de 20 años; esta casado con la señora Olga Peralta de 50 años de edad, juntos formaron una hermosa familia conformada de dos hijas adolescentes y un varón.

Agustín empezó trabajando para otras personas donde adquirió muchos conocimientos del negocio, después de mucho esfuerzo logró montar su taller propio, en donde actualmente realiza todo tipo de trabajos sobre hierro tales como: portones, verjas de protección para ventanas y otros. Su cónyuge le ayuda con los gastos familiares ya que la misma se dedica a las confecciones de manteles de ao poí (el ao´poí es un tejido típico del Paraguay que se utiliza para confecciones varias como ropas, manteles, etc.) y uno de sus hijos ya cuenta con estabilidad laboral.

 Acudió a Fundación Paraguaya para solicitar dicho crédito para la compra de  una nueva compresora, porque la que tiene esta obsoleta. Será de gran ayuda ya que cuenta con clientes muy exigentes.
texts.en:
Agustín is 62 years old and has operated a steel workshop for more than 20 years. He is married to Olga Peralta, 50, and they have a beautiful family which includes two adolescent daughters and one son.

Agustín started out working for other people and learned a lot about business. After much effort, he managed to open his own shop where he makes all sorts of items from metal, such as gates, window grates, etc. His wife helps with household expenses by making tablecloths of ao po’i (traditional Paraguayan needlework), and one of the children also has steady work.

Agustín went to Fundación Paraguaya to ask for this loan to purchase a new air compressor for his shop, as the one he has is worn out. This would be a big help in his business, as many of his clients are very demanding.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de una compresora industrial

loans.name: Yabana

texts.en:
Yabana E. sells beer in a bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and sodas to sell. Yabana is 28 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has 6 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy beer and sodas to sell

loans.name: Maurice

texts.en:
Maurice is 32 years old. He is married and has two children ages 1 and 17 years old. He also cares for two dependents from another family. Maurice's wife works, as well, selling clothing at a local store. She earns 30,000 RWF/month (approximately $US 60.00). The K. family lives in the Gasabo District, a region of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.  

Maurice opened a music studio and recording business just last year. He also sells musical instruments. Maurice is proud to be a self-employed businessman. The hours of his business require that he works from 8 AM to 6 PM every day except Sunday. He employs one person in his business as a helper.

Maurice is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand his business by buying musical instruments to sell and buying a computer to compose and record music. Maurice hopes his customers will be pleased with these new offerings. With this loan, Maurice hopes he will be able to expand his young business into a thriving enterprise and continue to support his family and build a secure future for them.

loans.use: Musical instruments and a computer for producing/recording music.

loans.name: Princess

texts.en:
Princess has a salon where she creates lovely hair styles for her customers. She also sells hair care supplies, like shampoo and hair extensions, and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She lives in Warri, Delta State. She is  52 years old and married with children. She is a hard-working woman. 

With her business, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family members. She is hoping for a loan of 170,000 NGN to purchase more hair supplies and drinks to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair materials and drinks to sell

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica sells secondhand clothes at retail prices to her customers. The demand for her secondhand clothes is high because there are people in her community that cannot afford new clothes. She hopes to own a boutique in the future.

Monica lives in Warri, Delta State. She is married with five children and she is 45 years old. She is a hardworking woman and with this business she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family members.

Monica hopes for a loan of 170,000 NGN to purchase more secondhand clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Freja

texts.en: Freja M. is currently in the business of selling local alcohol and charcoal and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal to sell. Freja is 30 years old and is married to a tailor. She has six children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a retail shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. The demand for her groceries is high in her community. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future.

Grace lives in Warri, Delta State. She is a hardworking woman, married with children. With this business, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family members. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 170,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 32-year-old man living with his mother and 2 unemployed sisters. He is the only provider for the family; he works as a computer programmer and maintainer since 2008 upon client’s request. Today, Ahmad is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy a car that will facilitate his transportation and he will be able to satisfy the demands of his clients immediately.

loans.use: Buy a car

loans.name: Progreso Y Solidaridad Group

texts.es:
El contacto para el  inicio del presente comité fue la Sra. Laura Alicia Díaz quien se informo acerca del programa y decidió conformar su  comité con sus vecinas y amigas. Las mismas invertirán su dinero en la compra D. leche, pan, azúcar, arroz,  verduras, frutas, productos lácteos, para su posterior venta y fabricación D. comestibles para su venta. Telas para la costura e insumos para peluquería, además D. productos D. belleza como maquillajes, cremas, perfumes, etc.

Las integrantes del comité realizan diferentes actividades comerciales, el detalle es como sigue:

texts.en:
The contact for the start of the present group was Laura Alicia Díaz. She was informed of the program and decided to form the group with her neighbors and friends. They will use the money to buy milk, bread, sugar, rice, vegetables, fruit, and dairy products. They will later sell them and make food to sell. Some will buy fabric for sewing, hairdressing supplies, or beauty products like make-up, cream, and perfume, etc. The group members are engaged in different commercial activities. loans.use: Buy clothes, drinks, meat, sausage, bread, herbs, oil, sweets, hairdressing products, sewing supplies like needles, thread, and scissors, etc.

loans.name: Laila

texts.en:
Laila is a 34-year-old single lady who takes care of four orphans left by her deceased elder sister. The four children are 6 through 12 years old. She lives in Nyarugenge, a region of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Laila has many responsibilities and expenses to cover in her family and that is why, 5 years ago, she decided to become a self-employed businesswoman. Laila sells women's clothes in her community which are in high demand in the local market. Laila works from 8 AM to 8 PM every day except Saturday.

Laila is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company so that she may purchase additional, attractive clothing to sell. With these new offerings, Laila hopes to attract more customers and to earn more profit. Laila plans to reinvest a portion of profits earned into her business. In addition, Laila will continue to pay school fees for her sister's children and gradually improve the life of her family.

loans.use: Purchase more clothes for sale
